[Wilson]86-wilson was chatting with [him]86-wilson when [Roxy]81-roxy arrived . [He]86-wilson asked [her]81-roxy how [she]81-roxy could bear to go off chambermaiding and leave [[her]81-roxy boys]1666-her boys ; and chaffingly offered to copy off a series of [their]1666-her boys finger - prints , reaching up to [their]1666-her boys twelfth year , for [her]81-roxy to remember them by ; but [she]81-roxy sobered in a moment , wondering if [he]86-wilson suspected anything ; then [she]81-roxy said [she]81-roxy believed [she]81-roxy did n't want them . [Wilson]86-wilson said to [himself]86-wilson , "[0-i] The drop of black blood in [her]515-her is superstitious ; [she]515-her thinks there 's some devilry , some witch - business about [my]0-i glass mystery somewhere ; [she]515-her used to come here with an old horseshoe in [her]515-her hand ; it could have been an accident , but [I]0-i doubt it . " [CHAPTER V. The Twins Thrill Dawson]113-dawson 's Landing . Training is everything . The peach was once a bitter almond ; cauliflower is nothing but cabbage with a college education.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar . Remark of [Dr. Baldwin]114-dr. baldwin 's , concerning [upstarts]1667-upstarts : [We]1668-we do n't care to eat toadstools that think [they]1666-her boys are truffles.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar . [Mrs. York Driscoll]115-mrs. york driscoll enjoyed two years of bliss with that prize , [Tom]102-tom -- bliss that was troubled a little at times , it is true , but bliss nevertheless ; then [she]115-mrs. york driscoll died , and [[her]115-mrs. york driscoll husband]1669-her husband and [[his]1669-her husband childless sister]1670-his childless sister , [Mrs. Pratt]77-mrs. pratt , continued the bliss - business at [the old stand]1671-the old stand . [Tom]102-tom was petted and indulged and spoiled to [his]102-tom entire content -- or nearly that . This went on till [he]102-tom was nineteen , then [he]102-tom was sent to [Yale]29-yale . [He]102-tom went handsomely equipped with "[515-her] conditions , " but otherwise [he]102-tom was not an object of distinction [there]1623-there . [He]102-tom remained at [Yale]29-yale two years , and then threw up the struggle . [He]102-tom came [home]1541-home with [his]102-tom manners a good deal improved ; [he]102-tom had lost [his]102-tom surliness and brusqueness , and was rather pleasantly soft and smooth , now ; [he]102-tom was furtively , and sometimes openly , ironical of speech , and given to gently touching [people]388-people on the raw , but [he]102-tom did it with a good - natured semiconscious air that carried it off safely , and kept [him]102-tom from getting into trouble . [He]102-tom was as indolent as ever and showed no very strenuous desire to hunt up an occupation . [People]388-people argued from this that [he]102-tom preferred to be supported by [[his]102-tom uncle]1660-his uncle until [[his]102-tom uncle]1660-his uncle 's shoes should become vacant . [He]102-tom brought back one or two new habits with [him]102-tom , one of which [he]102-tom rather openly practised -- tippling -- but concealed another which was gambling . It would not do to gamble where [[his]102-tom uncle]1660-his uncle could hear of it ; [he]102-tom knew that quite well . [Tom]102-tom 's Eastern polish was not popular among [the young people]1679-the young people . [They]1679-the young people could have endured it , perhaps , if [Tom]102-tom had stopped [there]1623-there ; but [he]102-tom wore gloves , and that [they]1679-the young people could n't stand , and would n't ; so [he]102-tom was mainly without [society]1681-society . [He]102-tom brought [home]1541-home with [him]102-tom a suit of clothes of such exquisite style and cut and fashion,--Eastern fashion , city fashion,--that it filled [everybody]367-everybody with anguish and was regarded as a peculiarly wanton affront . [He]102-tom enjoyed the feeling which [he]102-tom was exciting , and paraded [the town]289-the town serene and happy all day ; but [the young fellows]1685-the young fellows set [a tailor]1686-a tailor to work that night , and when [Tom]102-tom started out on [his]102-tom parade next morning [he]102-tom found [the old deformed negro bell - ringer]1687-the old deformed negro bell - ringer straddling along in [his]102-tom wake tricked out in a flamboyant curtain - calico exaggeration of [his]102-tom finery , and imitating [his]102-tom fancy Eastern graces as well as [he]102-tom could . [Tom]102-tom surrendered , and after that clothed [himself]102-tom in the local fashion . But [the dull country town]1688-the dull country town was tiresome to [him]102-tom , since [his]102-tom acquaintanceship with [livelier regions]1689-livelier regions , and it grew daily more and more so . [He]102-tom began to make little trips to [St. Louis]8-st. louis for refreshment . There [he]102-tom found companionship to suit [him]102-tom , and pleasures to [his]102-tom taste , along with more freedom , in some particulars , than [he]102-tom could have at [home]1541-home . So , during the next two years [his]102-tom visits to [the city]1691-the city grew in frequency and [his]102-tom tarryings there grew steadily longer in duration . [He]102-tom was getting into deep waters . [He]102-tom was taking chances , privately , which might get [him]102-tom into trouble some day -- in fact , did . [Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll had retired from the bench and from all business activities in 1850 , and had now been comfortably idle three years . [He]88-judge driscoll was president of [the Free - thinkers]1692-the free - thinkers ' Society , and [Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson was [the other member]1693-the other member . [The society]1694-the society 's weekly discussions were now [the old lawyer]1695-the old lawyer 's main interest in life . [Pudd'nhead]86-wilson was still toiling in obscurity at the bottom of the ladder , under the blight of that unlucky remark which [he]86-wilson had let fall twenty - three years before about the dog . [Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll was [[his]88-judge driscoll friend]1696-his friend , and claimed that [he]88-judge driscoll had a mind above the average , but that was regarded as one of [the Judge]315-the judge 's whims , and it failed to modify the public opinion . Or rather , that was one of the reasons why it failed , but there was another and better one . If [the Judge]315-the judge had stopped with bare assertion , it would have had a good deal of effect ; but [he]88-judge driscoll made the mistake of trying to prove [his]88-judge driscoll position . For some years [Wilson]86-wilson had been privately at work on a whimsical almanac , for [his]86-wilson amusement -- a calendar , with a little dab of ostensible philosophy , usually in ironical form , appended to each date ; and [the Judge]315-the judge thought that these quips and fancies of [Wilson]86-wilson 's were neatly turned and cute ; so [he]88-judge driscoll carried a handful of them around , one day , and read them to [some of [the chief citizens]1701-the chief citizens]1700-some of the chief citizens . But irony was not for [those people]1702-those people ; [their]1702-those people mental vision was not focussed for it . [They]1702-those people read those playful trifles in the solidest earnest , and decided without hesitancy that if there had ever been any doubt that [Dave Wilson]84-wilson was a pudd'nhead -- which there hadn't -- this revelation removed that doubt for good and all . That is just the way in [this world]1703-this world ; [an enemy]1704-an enemy can partly ruin [a man]432-a man , but it takes [a good - natured injudicious friend]1706-a good - natured injudicious friend to complete the thing and make it perfect . After this [the Judge]315-the judge felt tenderer than ever toward [Wilson]84-wilson , and surer than ever that [his]84-wilson calendar had merit . [Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll could be [a free - thinker]322-a free - thinker and still hold [his]88-judge driscoll place in [society]1681-society because [he]88-judge driscoll was [the person of most consequence in [the community]319-the community]1710-the person of most consequence in the community , and therefore could venture to go [his]88-judge driscoll own way and follow out [his]88-judge driscoll own notions . [The other member of [[his]88-judge driscoll pet organization]1713-his pet organization]1712-the other member of his pet organization was allowed the like liberty because [he]1712-the other member of his pet organization was [a cipher in the estimation of [the public]1715-the public]1714-a cipher in the estimation of the public , and [nobody]1501-nobody attached any importance to what [he]1712-the other member of his pet organization thought or did . [He]1712-the other member of his pet organization was liked , [he]1712-the other member of his pet organization was welcome enough all around , but [he]1712-the other member of his pet organization simply did n't count for anything . [The widow Cooper]91-ole miss cooper -- affectionately called "[117-aunt patsy] [aunt Patsy]117-aunt patsy " by [everybody]367-everybody -- lived in [a snug and comely cottage]1718-a snug and comely cottage with [[her]91-ole miss cooper daughter]1719-her daughter [Rowena]118-rowena , who was nineteen , romantic , amiable , and very pretty , but otherwise of no consequence . [Rowena]118-rowena had [a couple of young brothers]1720-a couple of young brothers -- also of no consequence . [The widow]1721-the widow had [a large spare room which [she]1721-the widow let to [a lodger]1723-a lodger , with board , when [she]1721-the widow could find one]1722-a large spare room which she let to a lodger , with board , when she could find one , but [this room]1724-this room had been empty for a year now , to [her]1721-the widow sorrow . [Her]1721-the widow income was only sufficient for the family support , and [she]1721-the widow needed the lodging - money for trifling luxuries . But now , at last , on a flaming June day , [she]1721-the widow found [herself]1721-the widow happy ; [her]1721-the widow tedious wait was ended ; [her]1721-the widow year - worn advertisement had been answered ; and not by [a village applicant]1725-a village applicant , oh , no!--this letter was from away off yonder in [the dim great world]1726-the dim great world to [the North]30-the north : it was from [St. Louis]8-st. louis . [She]1721-the widow sat on [[her]1721-the widow porch]1727-her porch gazing out with unseeing eyes upon [the shining reaches of [the mighty Mississippi]7-the mississippi]1728-the shining reaches of the mighty mississippi , [her]1721-the widow thoughts steeped in [her]1721-the widow good fortune . Indeed , it was specially good fortune , for [she]1721-the widow was to have [two lodgers]1729-two lodgers instead of one . [She]1721-the widow had read the letter to [the family]1730-the family , and [Rowena]118-rowena had danced away to see to the cleaning and airing of [the room]1731-the room by [the slave woman]1732-the slave woman [Nancy]92-nancy , and [the boys]1605-the boys had rushed abroad in [the town]289-the town to spread the great news , for it was matter of public interest , and [the public]1715-the public would wonder and not be pleased if not informed . Presently [Rowena]118-rowena returned , all ablush with joyous excitement , and begged for a re - reading of the letter . It was framed thus : [Honored Madam]1736-honored madam : [[My]1741-italians brother]1737-my brother and [I]1741-italians have seen [your]1721-the widow advertisement , by chance , and beg leave to take [the room [you]1721-the widow offer]1738-the room you offer . [We]1739-we are twenty - four years of age and [twins]1740-twins . [We]1739-we are [Italians]1741-italians by birth , but have lived long in [the various countries of [Europe]32-europe]1742-the various countries of europe , and several years in [the United States]33-the united states . [Our]1739-we names are [Luigi]119-luigi and [Angelo Capello]120-angelo . [You]1721-the widow desire but [one guest]1743-one guest ; but [dear Madam]1744-dear madam , if [you]1721-the widow will allow [us]1739-we to pay for two , [we]1739-we will not incommode [you]1721-the widow . [We]1739-we shall be down Thursday . "[1741-italians] [Italians]1741-italians ! How romantic ! Just think , [ma]517-ma -- there 's never been one in [this town]518-this town , and [everybody]367-everybody will be dying to see [them]520-they , and [they]520-they 're all [ours]521-ours ! Think of that ! " "[517-ma] Yes , [I]0-i reckon [they]520-they 'll make a grand stir . " "[520-they] Oh , indeed [they]520-they will . [The whole town]522-the whole town will be on [its]522-the whole town head ! Think -- [they've]520-they been in [Europe]32-europe and everywhere ! There 's never been [a traveler in [this town]518-this town]523-a traveler in this town before . [Ma]121-ma , [I]0-i should n't wonder if [they]520-they 've seen [kings]1497-kings ! " "[1497-kings] Well , a body ca n't tell , but [they]520-they 'll make stir enough , without that . " "[520-they] Yes , that 's of course . [Luigi]119-luigi -- [Angelo]120-angelo . [They]520-they 're lovely names ; and so grand and foreign -- not like [Jones]122-jones and [Robinson]123-justice robinson and such . Thursday [they]520-they are coming , and this is only Tuesday ; it 's a cruel long time to wait . Here comes [Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll in at the gate . [He]88-judge driscoll 's heard about it . [I]0-i 'll go and open the door . " [The Judge]315-the judge was full of congratulations and curiosity . The letter was read and discussed . Soon [Justice Robinson]123-justice robinson arrived with more congratulations , and there was a new reading and a new discussion . This was the beginning . [Neighbor]124-neighbor after [neighbor , of both sexes]1746-neighbor , of both sexes , followed , and [the procession]1747-the procession drifted in and out all day and evening and all Wednesday and Thursday . The letter was read and re - read until it was nearly worn out ; [everybody]367-everybody admired its courtly and gracious tone , and smooth and practised style , [everybody]367-everybody was sympathetic and excited , and [the Coopers]125-the coopers were steeped in happiness all the while . [The boats]1750-the boats were very uncertain in low water , in these primitive times . This time [the Thursday boat]1751-the thursday boat had not arrived at ten at night -- so [the people]332-the people had waited at [the landing]1753-the landing all day for nothing ; [they]332-the people were driven to [[their]332-the people homes]1754-their homes by a heavy storm without having had a view of [the illustrious foreigners]1755-the illustrious foreigners . Eleven o'clock came ; and [the Cooper house]1756-the cooper house was the only one in [the town]289-the town that still had lights burning . The rain and thunder were booming yet , and [the anxious family]1758-the anxious family were still waiting , still hoping . At last there was a knock at the door and [the family]1730-the family jumped to open it . [Two negro men]1760-two negro men entered , each carrying a trunk , and proceeded up - stairs toward [the guest - room]1761-the guest - room . Then entered [the twins]1762-the twins -- [the handsomest , the best dressed , the most distinguished - looking pair of [young fellows the West]1764-young fellows the west had ever seen]1763-the handsomest , the best dressed , the most distinguished - looking pair of young fellows the west had ever seen . [One]345-one was a little fairer than the other , but otherwise [they]1762-the twins were [exact duplicates]1766-exact duplicates . CHAPTER VI . Swimming in [Glory]34-glory . Let [us]1767-us endeavor so to live that when [we]1767-us come to die even [the undertaker]1768-the undertaker will be [sorry.--Pudd'nhead Wilson]84-wilson 's Calendar . Habit is habit , and not to be flung out of the window by [any man]1769-any man , but coaxed down - stairs a step at a time.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]84-wilson 's Calendar . At breakfast in the morning [the twins]1762-the twins ' charm of manner and easy and polished bearing made speedy conquest of [the family]1730-the family 's good graces . All constraint and formality quickly disappeared , and the friendliest feeling succeeded . [Aunt Patsy]117-aunt patsy called [them]1762-the twins by [their]1762-the twins Christian names almost from the beginning . [She]117-aunt patsy was full of the keenest curiosity about [them]1762-the twins , and showed it ; [they]1762-the twins responded by talking about [themselves]1762-the twins , which pleased [her]117-aunt patsy greatly . It presently appeared that in [their]1762-the twins early youth [they]1762-the twins had known poverty and hardship . As the talk wandered along [the old lady]1772-the old lady watched for the right place to drop in a question or two concerning that matter , and when [she]1772-the old lady found it [she]1772-the old lady said to [the blond twin who was now doing the biographies in [his]1773-the blond twin who was now doing the biographies in his turn turn]1773-the blond twin who was now doing the biographies in his turn while [the brunette one]1774-the brunette one rested-- "[0-i] If it ai n't asking what [I]0-i ought not to ask , [Mr. Angelo]126-mr. angelo , how did [you]126-mr. angelo come to be so friendless and in such trouble when [you]126-mr. angelo were little ? Do [you]126-mr. angelo mind telling ? But do n't if [you]126-mr. angelo do . " "[126-mr. angelo] Oh , [we]526-we do n't mind it at all , [madam]527-madam ; in [our]526-we case it was merely misfortune , and [nobody]1501-nobody 's fault . [[Our]526-we parents]529-our parents were well to do , there in [Italy]35-italy , and [we]526-we were [[their]529-our parents only child]530-their only child . [We]526-we were of [the old Florentine nobility"--Rowena]1775-the old florentine nobility"--rowena 's heart gave a great bound , [her]1775-the old florentine nobility"--rowena nostrils expanded , and a fine light played in [her]1775-the old florentine nobility"--rowena eyes--"and[1775-the old florentine nobility"--rowena] when the war broke out [[my]0-i father]531-my father was on the losing side and had to fly for [his]531-my father life . [[His]531-my father estates]532-his estates were confiscated , [his]531-my father personal property seized , and there [we]526-we were , in [Germany]36-germany , [strangers]533-strangers , [friendless]534-friendless , and in fact [paupers]535-paupers . [[My]0-i brother]1737-my brother and [I]0-i were ten years old , and well educated for that age , very studious , very fond of [our]526-we books , and well grounded in the German , French , Spanish , and English languages . Also , [we]526-we were marvelous musical prodigies -- if [you]537-you will allow [me]0-i to say it , it being only the truth . " [[Our]526-we father]1776-our father survived [his]531-my father misfortunes only a month , [[our]526-we mother]1777-our mother soon followed [him]531-my father , and [we]526-we were alone in [the world]263-the world . [[Our]526-we parents]529-our parents could have made [themselves]529-our parents comfortable by exhibiting [us]526-we as a show , and [they]529-our parents had many and large offers ; but the thought revolted [their]529-our parents pride , and [they]529-our parents said [they]529-our parents would starve and die first . But what [they]529-our parents would n't consent to do [we]526-we had to do without the formality of consent . [We]526-we were seized for the debts occasioned by [their]529-our parents illness and [their]529-our parents funerals , and placed among the attractions of [a cheap museum in [Berlin]37-berlin]1780-a cheap museum in berlin to earn the liquidation money . It took [us]526-we two years to get out of that slavery . [We]526-we traveled all about [Germany]36-germany receiving no wages , and not even [[our]526-we keep]1781-our keep . [We]526-we had to be exhibited for nothing , and beg [our]526-we bread . "[537-you] Well , [madam]527-madam , the rest is not of much consequence . When [we]539-we escaped from that slavery at twelve years of age , [we]539-we were in some respects [men]540-men . [Experience]127-experience had taught [us]539-we some valuable things ; among others , how to take care of [ourselves]539-we , how to avoid and defeat sharks and sharpers , and how to conduct [our]539-we own business for [our]539-we own profit and without [other people]541-other people 's help . [We]539-we traveled everywhere -- years and years -- picking up smatterings of strange tongues , familiarizing [ourselves]539-we with strange sights and strange customs , accumulating an education of a wide and varied and curious sort . It was a pleasant life . [We]539-we went to [Venice]9-venice -- to [London]38-london , [Paris]39-paris , [Russia]40-russia , [India]41-india , [China]42-china , [Japan--]43-japan-- " At this point [Nancy]92-nancy [the slave woman]1732-the slave woman thrust [her]1732-the slave woman head in at the door and exclaimed : "[128-ole missus] [Ole Missus]128-ole missus , [de house]542-de house is plum ' jam full o ' [people]388-people , en dey 's jes a - spi'lin ' to see [de gen'lmen]129-de gen'lmen ! " [She]1732-the slave woman indicated [the twins]1762-the twins with a nod of [her]1732-the slave woman head , and tucked it back out of sight again . It was a proud occasion for [the widow]1721-the widow , and [she]1732-the slave woman promised [herself]1732-the slave woman high satisfaction in showing off [her]1732-the slave woman fine foreign birds before [[her]1732-the slave woman neighbors]1785-her neighbors and [friends]1786-friends -- [simple folk who had hardly ever seen [a foreigner of any kind]1788-a foreigner of any kind]1787-simple folk who had hardly ever seen a foreigner of any kind , and [never one of any distinction or style]1789-never one of any distinction or style . Yet [her]1732-the slave woman feeling was moderate indeed when contrasted with [Rowena]118-rowena 's . [Rowena]118-rowena was in the clouds , [she]118-rowena walked on air ; this was to be the greatest day , the most romantic episode , in the colorless history of [that dull country town]1790-that dull country town . [She]1732-the slave woman was to be familiarly near the source of its glory and feel the full flood of it pour over [her]1732-the slave woman and about [her]1732-the slave woman ; [the other girls]1791-the other girls could only gaze and envy , not partake . [The widow]1721-the widow was ready , [Rowena]118-rowena was ready , so also were [the foreigners]1793-the foreigners . [The party]1794-the party moved along [the hall]1795-the hall , [the twins]1762-the twins in advance , and entered the open parlor door , whence issued a low hum of conversation . [The twins]1762-the twins took a position near the door , [the widow]1721-the widow stood at [Luigi]119-luigi 's side , [Rowena]118-rowena stood beside [Angelo]126-mr. angelo , and the march - past and the introductions began . [The widow]1721-the widow was all smiles and contentment . [She]1721-the widow received the procession and passed it on to [Rowena]118-rowena . "[130-sister cooper"--hand] Good mornin ' , [Sister Cooper"--hand]130-sister cooper"--hand - shake . [None of these visitors]1800-none of these visitors was at ease , but , being [honest people]1801-honest people , [they]1800-none of these visitors did n't pretend to be . [None of [them]1800-none of these visitors]1802-none of them had ever seen [a person bearing a title of nobility]1803-a person bearing a title of nobility before , and [none]437-none had been expecting to see [one]345-one now , consequently the title came upon [them]1800-none of these visitors as a kind of pile - driving surprise and caught [them]1800-none of these visitors unprepared . [A few]1806-a few tried to rise to the emergency , and got out an awkward "[545-my lord] [[My]0-i lord]545-my lord , " or "[545-my lord] [[Your]546-your lordship]547-your lordship , " or something of that sort , but [the great majority]1807-the great majority were overwhelmed by the unaccustomed word and its dim and awful associations with gilded courts and stately ceremony and anointed kingship , so [they]1807-the great majority only fumbled through the hand - shake and passed on , speechless . Now and then , as happens at all receptions everywhere , [a more than ordinary friendly soul]1808-a more than ordinary friendly soul blocked the procession and kept it waiting while [he]1808-a more than ordinary friendly soul inquired how [the brothers]1809-the brothers liked [the village]356-the village , and how long [they]548-they were going to stay , and if [[their]548-they families]1811-their families were well , and dragged in the weather , and hoped it would get cooler soon , and all that sort of thing , so as to be able to say , when [they]548-they got [home]1541-home , "[547-your lordship] [I]0-i had quite a long talk with [them]548-they " ; but [nobody]1501-nobody did or said anything of a regrettable kind , and so the great affair went through to the end in a creditable and satisfactory fashion . General conversation followed , and [the twins]1762-the twins drifted about from [group]1815-group to group , talking easily and fluently and winning approval , compelling admiration and achieving favor from all . [The widow]1721-the widow followed [their]1762-the twins conquering march with a proud eye , and every now and then [Rowena]118-rowena said to [herself]118-rowena with deep satisfaction , "[545-my lord] And to think [they]548-they are [ours]549-ours -- all [ours]549-ours ! " There were no idle moments for [mother]1817-mother or [daughter]1818-daughter . Eager inquiries concerning [the twins]1762-the twins were pouring into [their]1762-the twins enchanted ears all the time ; each was the constant center of [a group of [breathless listeners]1821-breathless listeners]1820-a group of breathless listeners ; [each]1822-each recognized that [she]118-rowena knew now for the first time the real meaning of that great word Glory , and perceived the stupendous value of it , and understood why [men in all ages]1823-men in all ages had been willing to throw away meaner happinesses , treasure , life itself , to get a taste of its sublime and supreme joy . [Napoleon]135-napoleon and all [his]135-napoleon kind stood accounted for -- and justified . When [Rowena]118-rowena had at last done all [her]118-rowena duty by [the people in [the parlor]1825-the parlor]1824-the people in the parlor , [she]118-rowena went up - stairs to satisfy the longings of an overflow - meeting there , for [the parlor]1825-the parlor was not big enough to hold [all the comers]1827-all the comers . Again [she]118-rowena was besieged by [eager questioners]1828-eager questioners and again [she]118-rowena swam in sunset seas of glory . When the forenoon was nearly gone , [she]118-rowena recognized with a pang that this most splendid episode of [her]118-rowena life was almost over , that nothing could prolong it , that nothing quite its equal could ever fall to [her]118-rowena fortune again . But never mind , it was sufficient unto itself , the grand occasion had moved on an ascending scale from the start , and was a noble and memorable success . If [the twins]1762-the twins could but do some crowning act , now , to climax it , something unusual , something startling , something to concentrate upon [themselves]1762-the twins [the company]1830-the company 's loftiest admiration , something in the nature of an electric surprise-- Here a prodigious slam - banging broke out below , and [everybody]367-everybody rushed down to see . It was [the twins]1762-the twins knocking out a classic four - handed piece on the piano , in great style . [Rowena]118-rowena was satisfied -- satisfied down to the bottom of [her]118-rowena heart . [The young strangers]1833-the young strangers were kept long at the piano . [The villagers]1834-the villagers were astonished and enchanted with the magnificence of [their]1762-the twins performance , and could not bear to have [them]1762-the twins stop . All the music that [they]1762-the twins had ever heard before seemed spiritless prentice - work and barren of grace or charm when compared with these intoxicating floods of melodious sound . [They]1762-the twins realized that for once in [their]1762-the twins lives [they]1762-the twins were hearing [masters]1835-masters . CHAPTER VII . [The Unknown Nymph]1836-the unknown nymph One of the most striking differences between a cat and a lie is that a cat has only nine lives.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]84-wilson 's Calendar . [The company]1830-the company broke up reluctantly , and drifted toward [[their]1762-the twins several homes]1838-their several homes , chatting with vivacity , and all agreeing that it would be many a long day before [[Dawson]113-dawson 's Landing]1644-dawson 's landing would see the equal of this one again . [The twins]1762-the twins had accepted several invitations while the reception was in progress , and had also volunteered to play some duets at an amateur entertainment for the benefit of [a local charity]1841-a local charity . Society was eager to receive [them]1762-the twins to [its]1841-a local charity bosom . [Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll had the good fortune to secure [them]1762-the twins for an immediate drive , and to be the first to display [them]1762-the twins in public . [They]1762-the twins entered [his]88-judge driscoll buggy with [him]88-judge driscoll , and were paraded down [the main street]268-the main street , [everybody]367-everybody flocking to the windows and [sidewalks]1844-sidewalks to see . [The Judge]315-the judge showed [the strangers]1846-the strangers [the new graveyard]1847-the new graveyard , and [the jail]1848-the jail , and where [the richest man]1849-the richest man lived , and [[the Freemasons]1850-the freemasons ' hall]1851-the freemasons ' hall , and [the Methodist church]1852-the methodist church , and [the Presbyterian church]1853-the presbyterian church , and where [the Baptist church]1854-the baptist church was going to be when [they]1762-the twins got some money to build [it]1854-the baptist church with , and showed [them]1846-the strangers [the town hall]1855-the town hall and [the slaughter - house]1856-the slaughter - house , and got out [the independent fire company]1857-the independent fire company in uniform and had [them]1846-the strangers put out an imaginary fire ; then [he]315-the judge let [them]1846-the strangers inspect the muskets of [the militia company]1858-the militia company , and poured out an exhaustless stream of enthusiasm over all these splendors , and seemed very well satisfied with the responses [he]315-the judge got , for [the twins]1762-the twins admired [his]315-the judge admiration , and paid [him]315-the judge back the best [they]1762-the twins could , though [they]1762-the twins could have done better if some fifteen or sixteen hundred thousand previous experiences of this sort in [various countries]1860-various countries had not already rubbed off a considerable part of the novelty of it . [The Judge]315-the judge laid [himself]315-the judge out hospitably to make [them]1846-the strangers have a good time , and if there was a defect anywhere it was not [his]315-the judge fault . [He]315-the judge told [them]1846-the strangers a good many humorous anecdotes , and always forgot the nub , but [they]1846-the strangers were always able to furnish it , for these yarns were of a pretty early vintage , and [they]1846-the strangers had had many a rejuvenating pull at [them]1846-the strangers before . And [he]315-the judge told [them]1846-the strangers all about [his]315-the judge several dignities , and how [he]315-the judge had held this and that and the other place of honor or profit , and had once been to the legislature , and was now president of [the Society of Free - thinkers]1862-the society of free - thinkers . [He]315-the judge said [the society]1694-the society had been in existence four years , and already had [two members]1864-two members , and was firmly established . [He]315-the judge would call for [the brothers]1809-the brothers in the evening if [they]1809-the brothers would like to attend a meeting of it . Accordingly [he]315-the judge called for [them]1809-the brothers , and on the way [he]315-the judge told [them]1809-the brothers all about [Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson , in order that [they]1809-the brothers might get a favorable impression of [him]86-wilson in advance and be prepared to like [him]86-wilson . This scheme succeeded -- the favorable impression was achieved . Later it was confirmed and solidified when [Wilson]86-wilson proposed that out of courtesy to [the strangers]1846-the strangers the usual topics be put aside and the hour be devoted to conversation upon ordinary subjects and the cultivation of friendly relations and good - fellowship,--a proposition which was put to vote and carried . The hour passed quickly away in lively talk , and when it was ended [the lonesome and neglected Wilson]86-wilson was richer by [two friends]1867-two friends than [he]315-the judge had been when it began . [He]315-the judge invited [the twins]1762-the twins to look in at [[his]315-the judge lodgings]1869-his lodgings , presently , after disposing of an intervening engagement , and [they]1762-the twins accepted with pleasure . Toward the middle of the evening [they]1762-the twins found [themselves]1762-the twins on [the road to [[his]315-the judge house]344-his house]1870-the road to his house . [Pudd'nhead]86-wilson was at [home]1541-home waiting for [them]1762-the twins and putting in [his]86-wilson time puzzling over a thing which had come under [his]86-wilson notice that morning . The matter was this : [He]86-wilson happened to be up very early -- at dawn , in fact ; and [he]86-wilson crossed [the hall]1795-the hall which divided [[his]86-wilson cottage]1874-his cottage through the center , and entered [a room]1875-a room to get something there . The window of [the room]1731-the room had no curtains , for that side of [the house]247-the house had long been unoccupied , and through this window [he]86-wilson caught sight of something which surprised and interested [him]86-wilson . It was [a young woman]1878-a young woman -- [a young woman where properly no young woman]1879-a young woman where properly no young woman belonged ; for [she]1878-a young woman was in [[Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll 's house]373-judge driscoll 's house , and in [the bedroom]1881-the bedroom over [[the Judge]315-the judge 's private study or sitting - room]1883-the judge 's private study or sitting - room . This was [young [Tom Driscoll]83-tom 's bedroom]1884-young tom driscoll 's bedroom . [He]86-wilson and [the Judge]315-the judge , [[the Judge]315-the judge 's widowed sister]316-the judge 's widowed sister [Mrs. Pratt]77-mrs. pratt and [three negro servants]1888-three negro servants were [the only people who belonged in [the house]247-the house]1889-the only people who belonged in the house . Who , then , might [this young lady]1891-this young lady be ? [The two houses]1892-the two houses were separated by [an ordinary yard]1893-an ordinary yard , with a low fence running back through [its]1893-an ordinary yard middle from [the street]274-the street in front to [the lane]1895-the lane in the rear . The distance was not great , and [Wilson]86-wilson was able to see [the girl]421-the girl very well , the window - shades of [the room [she]421-the girl was in being up]1897-the room she was in being up , and the window also . [The girl]421-the girl had on a neat and trim summer dress , patterned in broad stripes of pink and white , and [her]421-the girl bonnet was equipped with a pink veil . [She]421-the girl was practising steps , gaits and attitudes , apparently ; [she]421-the girl was doing the thing gracefully , and was very much absorbed in [her]421-the girl work . Who could [she]421-the girl be , and how came [she]421-the girl to be in [young [Tom Driscoll]83-tom 's room]1899-young tom driscoll 's room ? [Wilson]86-wilson had quickly chosen a position from which [he]86-wilson could watch [the girl]421-the girl without running much risk of being seen by [her]421-the girl , and [he]86-wilson remained there hoping [she]421-the girl would raise [her]421-the girl veil and betray [her]421-the girl face . But [she]421-the girl disappointed [him]86-wilson . After a matter of twenty minutes [she]421-the girl disappeared , and although [he]86-wilson stayed at [his]86-wilson post half an hour longer , [she]421-the girl came no more . Toward noon [he]86-wilson dropped in at [the Judge 's]1901-the judge 's and talked with [Mrs. Pratt]77-mrs. pratt about the great event of the day , the levee of [the distinguished foreigners at [Aunt Patsy Cooper]117-aunt patsy 's]1902-the distinguished foreigners at aunt patsy cooper 's . [Wilson]86-wilson did not ask if there was a newcomer in [the house]247-the house , but [he]86-wilson asked questions that would have brought light - throwing answers as to that matter if [Mrs. Pratt]77-mrs. pratt had had any light to throw ; so [he]86-wilson went away satisfied that [he]86-wilson knew of things that were going on in [[her]77-mrs. pratt house]1907-her house of which [she]77-mrs. pratt [herself]77-mrs. pratt was not aware . [He]86-wilson was now waiting for [the twins]1762-the twins , and still puzzling over the problem of who [that girl]1909-that girl might be , and how [she]1909-that girl happened to be in [[that young fellow]1910-that young fellow 's room]1911-that young fellow 's room at daybreak in the morning . CHAPTER VIII . [Marse Tom Tramples]102-tom [His]102-tom Chance . The holy passion of Friendship is of so sweet and steady and loyal and enduring a nature that it will last through a whole lifetime , if not asked to lend [money.--Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar . Consider well the proportions of things . It is better to be [a young June - bug]1912-a young june - bug than an old bird of paradise.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar . It is necessary now , to hunt up [Roxy]81-roxy . At the time [she]81-roxy was set free and went away chambermaiding , [she]81-roxy was thirty - five . [She]81-roxy got a berth as [second chambermaid]1913-second chambermaid on [a [Cincinnati]44-cincinnati boat in the New [Orleans]13-orleans trade]1914-a cincinnati boat in the new orleans trade , [the Grand Mogul]136-the grand mogul . A couple of trips made [her]81-roxy wonted and easy - going at the work , and infatuated [her]81-roxy with the stir and adventure and independence of steamboat life . Then [she]81-roxy was promoted and became [head chambermaid]1915-head chambermaid . [She]81-roxy was a favorite with [the officers]1916-the officers , and exceedingly proud of [their]1916-the officers joking and friendly way with [her]81-roxy . During eight years [she]81-roxy served three parts of the year on [that boat]1917-that boat , and the winters on [a Vicksburg packet]1918-a vicksburg packet . But now for two months [she]81-roxy had had rheumatism in [her]81-roxy arms , and was obliged to let the wash - tub alone . So [she]81-roxy resigned . But [she]81-roxy was well fixed -- rich , as [she]81-roxy would have described it ; for [she]81-roxy had lived a steady life , and had banked four dollars every month in [New Orleans]23-new orleans as a provision for [her]81-roxy old age . [She]81-roxy said in the start that [she]81-roxy had "[547-your lordship] put shoes on [one bar'footed nigger]550-one bar'footed nigger to tromple on [her]550-one bar'footed nigger with , " and that one mistake like that was enough ; [she]81-roxy would be independent of [the human race]1919-the human race thenceforth forevermore if hard work and economy could accomplish it . When [the boat]1920-the boat touched the levee at [New Orleans]23-new orleans [she]81-roxy bade good - by to [[her]81-roxy comrades on [the Grand Mogul]136-the grand mogul]1921-her comrades on the grand mogul and moved [her]81-roxy kit ashore . But [she]81-roxy was back in a hour . [The bank]1922-the bank had gone to smash and carried [her]81-roxy four hundred dollars with it . [She]81-roxy was [a pauper]1659-a pauper , and homeless . [Also disabled bodily]1924-also disabled bodily , at least for the present . [The officers]1916-the officers were full of sympathy for [her]81-roxy in [her]81-roxy trouble , and made up a little purse for [her]81-roxy . [She]81-roxy resolved to go to [[her]81-roxy birthplace]1926-her birthplace ; [she]81-roxy had [[friends]1786-friends [there]1623-there among [the negroes]1930-the negroes]1928-friends there among the negroes , and [the unfortunate]1931-the unfortunate always help [the unfortunate]1931-the unfortunate , [she]81-roxy was well aware of that ; [those lowly comrades of [her]81-roxy youth]1933-those lowly comrades of her youth would not let [her]81-roxy starve . [She]81-roxy took [the little local packet at [Cairo]11-cairo]1934-the little local packet at cairo , and now [she]81-roxy was on the [home - stretch]1935-home - stretch . Time had worn away [her]81-roxy bitterness against [[her]81-roxy son]1627-her son , and [she]81-roxy was able to think of [him]1627-her son with serenity . [She]81-roxy put the vile side of [him]1627-her son out of [her]81-roxy mind , and dwelt only on recollections of [his]1627-her son occasional acts of kindness to [her]81-roxy . [She]81-roxy gilded and otherwise decorated these , and made them very pleasant to contemplate . [She]81-roxy began to long to see [him]1627-her son . [She]81-roxy would go and fawn upon [him]1627-her son , [slave]1937-slave - like -- for this would have to be [her]81-roxy attitude , of course -- and maybe [she]81-roxy would find that time had modified [him]1627-her son , and that [he]1627-her son would be glad to see [[his]1627-her son long - forgotten old nurse]1938-his long - forgotten old nurse and treat [her]1938-his long - forgotten old nurse gently . That would be lovely ; that would make [her]81-roxy forget [her]81-roxy woes and [her]81-roxy poverty . [Her]81-roxy poverty ! That thought inspired [her]81-roxy to add another castle to [her]81-roxy dream : maybe [he]1627-her son would give [her]81-roxy a trifle now and then -- maybe a dollar , once a month , say ; any little thing like that would help , oh , ever so much . By the time [she]81-roxy reached [[Dawson]113-dawson 's Landing]1644-dawson 's landing [she]81-roxy was [her]81-roxy old self again ; [her]81-roxy blues were gone , [she]81-roxy was in high feather . [She]81-roxy would get along , surely ; there were many kitchens where [the servants]1940-the servants would share [their]1940-the servants meals with [her]81-roxy , and also steal sugar and apples and other dainties for [her]81-roxy to carry [home]1541-home -- or give [her]81-roxy a chance to pilfer them [herself]81-roxy , which would answer just as well . And there was [the church]1942-the church . [She]81-roxy was [a more rabid and devoted Methodist]1943-a more rabid and devoted methodist than ever , and [her]81-roxy piety was no sham , but was strong and sincere . Yes , with plenty of creature comforts and [her]81-roxy old place in the amen - corner in [her]81-roxy possession again , [she]81-roxy would be perfectly happy and at peace thenceforward to the end . [She]81-roxy went to [[Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll 's kitchen]1944-judge driscoll 's kitchen first of all . [She]81-roxy was received [there]1623-there in great form and with vast enthusiasm . [Her]81-roxy wonderful travels , and [the strange countries [she]81-roxy had seen and the adventures [she]81-roxy had had]1946-the strange countries she had seen and the adventures she had had , made [her]81-roxy a marvel , and [a heroine of romance]1947-a heroine of romance . [The negroes]1930-the negroes hung enchanted upon the great story of [her]81-roxy experiences , interrupting [her]81-roxy all along with eager questions , with laughter , exclamations of delight and expressions of applause ; and [she]81-roxy was obliged to confess to [herself]81-roxy that if there was anything better in [this world]1703-this world than steamboating , it was the glory to be got by telling about it . [The audience]1950-the audience loaded [her]81-roxy stomach with [their]1950-the audience dinners , and then stole the pantry bare to load up [her]81-roxy basket . [Tom]102-tom was in [St. Louis]8-st. louis . [The servants]1940-the servants said [he]102-tom had spent the best part of [his]102-tom time [there]1623-there during the previous two years . [Roxy]81-roxy came every day , and had many talks about [the family]1730-the family and [its]1730-the family affairs . Once [she]81-roxy asked why [Tom]102-tom was away so much . [The ostensible "[547-your lordship] Chambers]95-chambers " said : "[551-de fac ' is] [De fac ' is]551-de fac ' is , [ole marster]552-ole marster kin git along better when [young marster]553-young marster 's away den [he]553-young marster kin when [he]553-young marster 's in [de town]554-de town ; yes , en [he]553-young marster love [him]553-young marster better , too ; so [he]553-young marster gives [him]553-young marster fifty dollahs a month-- " "[553-young marster] No , is dat so ? [Chambers]95-chambers , [you]95-chambers 's a - jokin ' , ai n't [you]95-chambers ? " "[95-chambers] ' Clah to goodness [I]0-i ai n't , [mammy]1472-mammy ; [Marse Tom]102-tom tole [me]0-i so [his]102-tom own self . But nemmine , ' tain't enough . " "[0-i] [My]0-i lan ' , what de reason ' tain't enough ? " "[0-i] Well , [I]0-i 's gwine to tell [you]1472-mammy , if [you]1472-mammy gimme [a chanst]556-a chanst , [mammy]1472-mammy . [De]558-de reason it ai n't enough is ' ca'se [Marse Tom]102-tom gambles . " [Roxy]81-roxy threw up [her]81-roxy hands in astonishment and [Chambers]95-chambers went on-- "[128-ole missus] [Ole marster]128-ole missus found it out , ' ca'se [he]128-ole missus had to pay two hundred dollahs for [Marse Tom]102-tom 's gamblin ' debts , en dat 's true , [mammy]1472-mammy , jes as dead certain as [you]1472-mammy 's bawn . " "[128-ole missus] Two -- hund'd -- dollahs ! Why , what is [you]0-i talkin ' 'bout ? Two -- hund'd -- dollahs . Sakes alive , it 's ' mos ' enough to buy [a tol'able good second - hand nigger wid]560-a tol'able good second - hand nigger wid . En [you]1472-mammy ai n't lyin ' , [honey?--you]1472-mammy would n't lie to [yo]1472-mammy ' ole mammy ? " "[1472-mammy] It 's [God]100-god 's own truth , jes as [I]0-i tell [you]1472-mammy -- [two hund'd dollahs]561-two hund'd dollahs -- [I]0-i wisht [I]0-i may never stir outen [my]0-i tracks if it ai n't so . En , oh , [my]0-i lan ' , [ole Marse]102-tom was jes a - hoppin ' ! [he]102-tom was b'ilin ' mad , [I]0-i tell [you]1472-mammy ! [He]102-tom tuck [']562-' n ' dissenhurrit [him]102-tom . " [He]0-i licked [his]0-i chops with relish after that stately word . [Roxy]81-roxy struggled with it a moment , then gave it up and said-- "[102-tom] Dissenwhiched [him]102-tom ? " "[102-tom] Dissenhurrit [him]102-tom . " "[102-tom] What 's dat ? What do it mean ? " "[102-tom] Means [he]102-tom bu'sted [de]563-de will . " "[102-tom] [Bu's]137-bu's -- [ted]564-ted [de]563-de will ! [He]102-tom would n't ever treat [him]102-tom so ! Take it back , [you]1472-mammy mis'able imitation nigger dat [I]0-i bore in sorrow en tribbilation . " [[Roxy]81-roxy 's pet castle]1954-roxy 's pet castle -- an occasional dollar from [Tom]102-tom 's pocket -- was tumbling to ruin before [her]81-roxy eyes . [She]81-roxy could not abide such a disaster as that ; [she]81-roxy could n't endure the thought of it . [Her]81-roxy remark amused [Chambers]95-chambers : "[565-yah] [Yah]565-yah - yah - yah ! [jes]566-jes listen to dat ! If [I]0-i 's imitation , what is [you]1472-mammy ? Bofe of [us]567-us is imitation white -- dat 's what [we]567-us is -- en pow'ful good imitation , too -- [yah]565-yah - yah - [yah!--we]568-yah!--we do n't ' mount to noth'n as [imitation niggers]569-imitation niggers ; en as for-- " "[570-shet] [Shet]570-shet up [yo]1472-mammy ' foolin ' , ' fo ' [I]0-i knock [you]1472-mammy side de head , en tell [me]0-i 'bout [de]571-de will . Tell [me]0-i ' tain't bu'sted -- do , [honey]1471-honey , en [I]0-i 'll never forgit [you]1471-honey . " "[0-i] Well , ' tain't--'ca'se [dey]573-dey 's a new one made , en [Marse Tom]102-tom 's all right ag'in . But what is [you]1471-honey in sich a sweat 'bout it for , [mammy]1472-mammy ? ' Tain't none o ' [your]1471-honey business [I]0-i do n't reckon . " "[0-i] ' Tain't none o ' [my]0-i business ? Whose business is it den , [I]0-i 'd like to know ? Wuz [I]0-i [[his]102-tom mother]575-his mother tell [he]102-tom was fifteen years old , or wusn't [I?--you]576-i?--you answer [me]0-i dat . En [you]1471-honey speck [I]0-i could see [him]102-tom turned out po ' en ornery on de worl ' en never care noth'n ' 'bout it ? [I]0-i reckon if [you]1471-honey 'd ever be'n [a mother yo'self]577-a mother yo'self , [Valet de Chambers]95-chambers , [you]1471-honey would n't talk [sich]578-sich foolishness as dat . " "[1471-honey] Well , [den]579-den , [ole Marse]102-tom forgive [him]102-tom en fixed up [de]102-tom will ag'in -- do dat satisfy [you]1471-honey ? " Yes , [she]1471-honey was satisfied now , and quite happy and sentimental over it . [She]1471-honey kept coming daily , and at last [she]1471-honey was told that [Tom]102-tom had come [home]1541-home . [She]1471-honey began to tremble with emotion , and straightway sent to beg [him]102-tom to let [his]102-tom "[1471-honey] po ' ole [nigger mammy]580-nigger mammy have jes one sight of [him]102-tom en die for joy . " [Tom]102-tom was stretched at [his]102-tom lazy ease on a sofa when [Chambers]95-chambers brought the petition . Time had not modified [his]102-tom ancient detestation of [the humble drudge and protector of [his]102-tom boyhood]1956-the humble drudge and protector of his boyhood ; it was still bitter and uncompromising . [He]102-tom sat up and bent a severe gaze upon the fair face of [the young fellow whose name [he]102-tom was unconsciously using and whose family rights [he]102-tom was enjoying]1957-the young fellow whose name he was unconsciously using and whose family rights he was enjoying . [He]102-tom maintained the gaze until [the victim of it]1958-the victim of it had become satisfactorily pallid with terror , then [he]102-tom said-- "[580-nigger mammy] What does [the old rip]581-the old rip want with [me]0-i ? " The petition was meekly repeated . "[581-the old rip] Who gave [you]582-you permission to come and disturb [me]0-i with the social attentions of [niggers]1468-niggers ? " [Tom]102-tom had risen . [The other young man]1959-the other young man was trembling now , visibly . [He]102-tom saw what was coming , and bent [his]102-tom head sideways , and put up [his]102-tom left arm to shield it . [Tom]102-tom rained cuffs upon the head and its shield , saying no word : [the victim]1960-the victim received each blow with a beseeching , "[138-marse tom!--oh] Please , [Marse Tom!--oh]138-marse tom!--oh , please , [Marse Tom]102-tom ! " Seven blows -- then [Tom]102-tom said , "[102-tom] Face the door -- march ! " [He]102-tom followed behind with one , two , three solid kicks . [The last one]1961-the last one helped [the pure - white slave]1962-the pure - white slave over the door - sill , and [he]1962-the pure - white slave limped away mopping [his]1962-the pure - white slave eyes with [his]1962-the pure - white slave old ragged sleeve . [Tom]102-tom shouted after [him]1962-the pure - white slave , "[584-you] Send [her]584-you in ! " Then [he]1962-the pure - white slave flung [himself]1962-the pure - white slave panting on the sofa again , and rasped out the remark , "[102-tom] [He]102-tom arrived just at the right moment ; [I]0-i was full to the brim with bitter thinkings , and [nobody]1501-nobody to take it out of . How refreshing it was ! [I]0-i feel better . " [[Tom]102-tom 's mother]1963-tom 's mother entered now , closing the door behind [her]1963-tom 's mother , and approached [[her]1963-tom 's mother son]1627-her son with all the wheedling and supplicating servilities that fear and interest can impart to the words and attitudes of [the born slave]1965-the born slave . [She]1963-tom 's mother stopped a yard from [[her]1963-tom 's mother boy]1629-her boy and made two or three admiring exclamations over [his]102-tom manly stature and general handsomeness , and [Tom]102-tom put an arm under [his]102-tom head and hoisted a leg over the sofa - back in order to look properly indifferent . "[0-i] [My]0-i lan ' , how [you]584-you is growed , [honey]1471-honey ! ' Clah to goodness , [I]0-i would n't a - knowed [you]584-you , [Marse Tom]102-tom ! ' deed [I]0-i would n't ! Look at [me]0-i good ; does [you]584-you ' member old Roxy?--does [you]584-you know [yo]584-you ' [old nigger mammy]587-old nigger mammy , [honey]1471-honey ? Well , now , [I]0-i kin lay down en die in peace , ' ca'se [I'se]0-i seed-- " "[0-i] Cut it short , ------ it , cut it short ! What is it [you]584-you want ? " "[584-you] [You]584-you heah dat ? Jes [the same old Marse Tom]589-the same old marse tom , al'ays so gay and funnin ' wid [de ole mammy]590-de ole mammy . [I]0-i ' uz jes as shore-- " "[0-i] Cut it short , [I]0-i tell [you]584-you , and get along ! What do [you]584-you want ? " This was a bitter disappointment . [Roxy]81-roxy had for so many days nourished and fondled and petted [her]81-roxy notion that [Tom]102-tom would be glad to see [[his]102-tom old nurse]1967-his old nurse , and would make [her]81-roxy proud and happy to the marrow with a cordial word or two , that it took two rebuffs to convince [her]81-roxy that [he]102-tom was not funning , and that [her]81-roxy beautiful dream was a fond and foolish vanity , a shabby and pitiful mistake . [She]81-roxy was hurt to the heart , and so ashamed that for a moment [she]81-roxy did not quite know what to do or how to act . Then [her]81-roxy breast began to heave , the tears came , and in [her]81-roxy forlornness [she]81-roxy was moved to try that other dream of [hers]81-roxy -- an appeal to [[her]81-roxy boy]1629-her boy 's charity ; and so , upon the impulse , and without reflection , [she]81-roxy offered [her]81-roxy supplication : "[584-you] Oh , [Marse Tom]102-tom , [de po ' ole mammy]591-de po ' ole mammy is in [sich]592-sich hard luck dese days ; en [she]591-de po ' ole mammy 's kinder crippled in [de]591-de po ' ole mammy arms and ca n't work , en if [you]102-tom could gimme a dollah -- on'y jes one little dol-- " [Tom]102-tom was on [his]102-tom feet so suddenly that [the supplicant]1969-the supplicant was startled into a jump [herself]81-roxy . "[102-tom] A dollar!--give [you]102-tom a dollar ! [I]0-i 've a notion to strangle [you]102-tom ! Is that [your]102-tom errand here ? Clear out ! and be quick about it ! " [Roxy]81-roxy backed slowly toward the door . When [she]81-roxy was half - way [she]81-roxy stopped , and said mournfully : "[102-tom] [Marse Tom]102-tom , [I]0-i nussed [you]102-tom when [you]102-tom was [a little baby]593-a little baby , en [I]0-i raised [you]102-tom all by [myself]0-i tell [you]102-tom was ' most [a young man]594-a young man ; en now [you]102-tom is young en rich , en [I]0-i is po ' en gitt'n ole , en [I]0-i come [heah]595-heah b'lievin ' dat [you]102-tom would he'p [de ole mammy]590-de ole mammy ' long down [de little road]597-de little road dat 's lef ' ' twix ' [her]590-de ole mammy en de grave , en-- " [Tom]102-tom relished this tune less than any that had preceded it , for it began to wake up a sort of echo in [his]102-tom conscience ; so [he]102-tom interrupted and said with decision , though without asperity , that [he]102-tom was not in a situation to help [her]590-de ole mammy , and was n't going to do it . "[102-tom] Ai n't [you]102-tom ever gwine to he'p [me]0-i , [Marse Tom]102-tom ? " "[102-tom] No ! Now go away and do n't bother [me]0-i any more . " [Roxy]81-roxy 's head was down , in an attitude of humility . But now the fires of [her]81-roxy old wrongs flamed up in [her]81-roxy breast and began to burn fiercely . [She]81-roxy raised [her]81-roxy head slowly , till it was well up , and at the same time [her]81-roxy great frame unconsciously assumed an erect and masterful attitude , with all the majesty and grace of [her]81-roxy vanished youth in it . [She]81-roxy raised [her]81-roxy finger and punctuated with it : "[102-tom] [You]102-tom has said de word . [You]102-tom has had [yo]102-tom ' chance , en [you]102-tom has trompled it under [yo]102-tom ' foot . When [you]102-tom git another one , [you]102-tom 'll git down on [yo]102-tom ' knees en beg for it ! " A cold chill went to [Tom]102-tom 's heart , [he]102-tom did n't know why ; for [he]102-tom did not reflect that such words , from such an incongruous source , and so solemnly delivered , could not easily fail of that effect . However , [he]102-tom did the natural thing : [he]102-tom replied with bluster and mockery : "[102-tom] [You]102-tom 'll give [me]0-i a chance -- [you]102-tom ! Perhaps [I]0-i 'd better get down on [my]0-i knees now ! But in case [I]0-i don't -- just for argument 's sake -- what 's going to happen , pray ? " "[102-tom] Dis is what is gwine to happen . [I]0-i 's gwine as straight to [[yo]102-tom ' uncle]598-yo ' uncle as [I]0-i kin walk , en tell [him]598-yo ' uncle every las ' thing [I]0-i knows 'bout [you]102-tom . " [Tom]102-tom 's cheek blenched , and [she]599-she saw it . Disturbing thoughts began to chase each other through [his]102-tom head . "[0-i] How can [she]599-she know ? And yet [she]599-she must have found out -- [she]599-she looks it . [I]0-i 've had the will back only three months , and am already deep in debt again , and moving heaven and earth to save [myself]0-i from exposure and destruction , with a reasonably fair show of getting the thing covered up if [I]0-i 'm let alone , and now [this fiend]600-this fiend has gone and found [me]0-i out somehow or other . [I]0-i wonder how much [she]599-she knows ? Oh , oh , oh , it 's enough to break a body 's heart ! But [I]0-i 've got to humor [her]599-she -- there 's no other way . " Then [he]0-i worked up a rather sickly sample of a gay laugh and a hollow chipperness of manner , and said : "[0-i] Well , well , [[Roxy]81-roxy dear]601-roxy dear , [old friends like [you]601-roxy dear and [me]0-i]602-old friends like you and me must n't quarrel . Here 's [your]601-roxy dear dollar -- now tell [me]0-i what [you]601-roxy dear know . " [He]0-i held out the wild - cat bill ; [she]599-she stood as [she]599-she was , and made no movement . It was [her]599-she turn to scorn persuasive foolery , now , and [she]599-she did not waste it . [She]599-she said , with a grim implacability in voice and manner which made [Tom]102-tom almost realize that even [a former slave]1970-a former slave can remember for ten minutes insults and injuries returned for compliments and flatteries received , and can also enjoy taking revenge for [them]1971-them when the opportunity offers : "[0-i] What does [I]0-i know ? [I]0-i 'll tell [you]601-roxy dear what [I]0-i knows . [I]0-i knows enough to bu'st dat will to flinders -- en more , mind [you]601-roxy dear , more ! " [Tom]102-tom was aghast . "[601-roxy dear] More ? " [he]102-tom said . "[601-roxy dear] What do [you]601-roxy dear call more ? Where 's there any room for more ? " [Roxy]81-roxy laughed a mocking laugh , and said scoffingly , with a toss of [her]81-roxy head , and [her]81-roxy hands on [her]81-roxy hips-- "[601-roxy dear] Yes!--oh , [I]0-i reckon ! Co'se [you]601-roxy dear 'd like to know -- wid [yo]601-roxy dear ' po ' [little ole rag dollah]603-little ole rag dollah . What [you]601-roxy dear reckon [I]0-i 's gwine to tell [you]601-roxy dear for?--you ai n't got no money . [I]0-i 's gwine to tell [[yo]601-roxy dear ' uncle]598-yo ' uncle -- en [I]0-i 'll do it dis minute , too -- he'll gimme five dollahs for de news , en mighty glad , too . " [She]81-roxy swung [herself]81-roxy around disdainfully , and started away . [Tom]102-tom was in a panic . [He]102-tom seized [her]81-roxy skirts , and implored [her]81-roxy to wait . [She]81-roxy turned and said , loftily-- "[0-i] Look - a - heah , what ' uz it [I]0-i tole [you]0-i ? " "[0-i] [You]0-i -- [you]0-i -- [I]0-i do n't remember anything . What was it [you]0-i told [me]0-i ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i tole [you]601-roxy dear dat [de]605-de next time [I]0-i give [you]0-i a chance [you]0-i 'd git down on [yo]0-i ' knees en beg for it . " [Tom]102-tom was stupefied for a moment . [He]102-tom was panting with excitement . Then [he]102-tom said : "[0-i] Oh , [Roxy]81-roxy , [you]81-roxy would n't require [[your]81-roxy young master]606-your young master to do such a horrible thing . [You]0-i ca n't mean it . " "[0-i] [I]0-i 'll let [you]601-roxy dear know mighty quick whether [I]0-i means it or not ! [You]601-roxy dear call [me]0-i names , en as good as spit on [me]0-i when [I]0-i comes here po ' en ornery en ' umble , to praise [you]601-roxy dear for bein ' growed up so fine en handsome , en tell [you]601-roxy dear how [I]0-i used to nuss [you]601-roxy dear en tend [you]601-roxy dear en watch [you]601-roxy dear when [you]601-roxy dear ' uz sick en had n't [no mother]607-no mother but [me]0-i in [de]608-de whole worl ' , en beg [you]601-roxy dear to give [de po ' ole nigger a dollah]609-de po ' ole nigger a dollah for to git [her]609-de po ' ole nigger a dollah som'n ' to eat , en [you]601-roxy dear call [me]0-i names -- names , [dad]610-dad blame [you]601-roxy dear ! [Yassir]139-yassir , [I]0-i gives [you]601-roxy dear jes one chance mo ' , and [dat]611-dat 's now , en it las ' on'y a half a second -- [you]601-roxy dear hear ? " [Tom]102-tom slumped to [his]102-tom knees and began to beg , saying-- "[601-roxy dear] [You]601-roxy dear see , [I]0-i 'm begging , and it 's honest begging , too ! Now tell [me]0-i , [Roxy]81-roxy , tell [me]0-i . " [The heir of two centuries of unatoned insult and outrage]1972-the heir of two centuries of unatoned insult and outrage looked down on [him]102-tom and seemed to drink in deep draughts of satisfaction . Then [she]81-roxy said-- "[81-roxy] [Fine nice young white gen'l'man]612-fine nice young white gen'l'man kneelin ' down to [a nigger - wench]613-a nigger - wench ! [I]0-i 's wanted to see [dat]614-dat jes once befo ' [I]0-i 's called . Now , [Gabr'el]140-gabr'el , blow de hawn , [I]0-i 's ready ... Git up ! " [Tom]102-tom did it . [He]102-tom said , humbly-- "[81-roxy] Now , [Roxy]81-roxy , do n't punish [me]0-i any more . [I]0-i deserved what [I]0-i 've got , but be good and let [me]0-i off with that . Do n't go to [uncle]615-uncle . Tell [me]0-i -- [I'll]0-i give [you]81-roxy the five dollars . " "[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i bet [you]81-roxy will ; en [you]81-roxy wo n't stop [dah]616-dah , [nuther]617-nuther . But [I]0-i ai n't gwine to tell [you]81-roxy heah-- " "[0-i] Good gracious , no ! " "[81-roxy] Is [you]81-roxy ' feared o ' [de ha'nted house]618-de ha'nted house ? " "[81-roxy] N - no . " "[81-roxy] Well , [den]579-den , [you]579-den come to [de ha'nted house]618-de ha'nted house 'bout ten or ' leven to - night , en climb up [de ladder]621-de ladder , ' ca'se de sta'r - steps is broke down , en [you]579-den 'll find [me]0-i . [I]0-i 's a - roostin ' in [de ha'nted house]618-de ha'nted house ' ca'se [I]0-i ca n't ' ford to roos ' nowhers ' else . " [She]81-roxy started toward the door , but stopped and said , "[0-i] Gimme de dollah bill ! " [He]0-i gave it to [her]81-roxy . [She]81-roxy examined it and said , "[0-i] H'm -- like enough de bank 's bu'sted . " [She]81-roxy started again , but halted again . "[0-i] Has [you]81-roxy got any whisky ? " "[81-roxy] Yes , a little . " "[81-roxy] Fetch it ! " [He]0-i ran to [[his]0-i room]1973-his room overhead and brought down a bottle which was two - thirds full . [She]81-roxy tilted it up and took a drink . [Her]81-roxy eyes sparkled with satisfaction , and [she]81-roxy tucked the bottle under [her]81-roxy shawl , saying , "[81-roxy] It 's prime . [I]0-i 'll take it along . " [Tom]102-tom humbly held the door for [her]81-roxy , and [she]81-roxy marched out as grim and erect as [a grenadier]1974-a grenadier . CHAPTER IX . [Tom]102-tom Practises Sycophancy . Why is it that [we]1975-we rejoice at a birth and grieve at a funeral ? It is because [we]1975-we are not [the person involved.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar]1976-the person involved.--pudd'nhead wilson 's calendar . It is easy to find fault , if one has that disposition . There was once [a man who , not being able to find any other fault with [his]1977-a man who , not being able to find any other fault with his coal coal]1977-a man who , not being able to find any other fault with his coal , complained that there were too many prehistoric toads in [it.--Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar . [Tom]102-tom flung [himself]102-tom on the sofa , and put [his]102-tom throbbing head in [his]102-tom hands , and rested [his]102-tom elbows on [his]102-tom knees . [He]102-tom rocked [himself]102-tom back and forth and moaned . "[0-i] [I]0-i 've knelt to [a nigger wench]623-a nigger wench ! " [he]102-tom muttered . "[0-i] [I]0-i thought [I]0-i had struck the deepest depths of degradation before , but oh , dear , it was nothing to this .... Well , there is one consolation , such as it is -- [I've]0-i struck bottom this time ; there 's nothing lower . " But that was a hasty conclusion . At ten that night [he]102-tom climbed the ladder in [the haunted house]1978-the haunted house , pale , weak and wretched . [Roxy]81-roxy was standing in the door of [one of [the rooms]1980-the rooms]1979-one of the rooms , waiting , for [she]81-roxy had heard [him]102-tom . [This]1981-this was [a two - story log house which had acquired the reputation a few years before of being haunted]1982-a two - story log house which had acquired the reputation a few years before of being haunted , and that was the end of [its]1981-this usefulness . [Nobody]1501-nobody would live in [it]1981-this afterward , or go near [it]1981-this by night , and [most people]1984-most people even gave [it]1981-this a wide berth in the daytime . As [it]1981-this had no competition , [it]1981-this was called [the haunted house]1978-the haunted house . [It]1981-this was getting crazy and ruinous , now , from long neglect . [It]1981-this stood three hundred yards beyond [[Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson 's house]1986-pudd'nhead wilson 's house , with nothing between but [vacancy]1987-vacancy . [It]1981-this was [the last house in [the town]289-the town at that end]1988-the last house in the town at that end . [Tom]102-tom followed [Roxy]81-roxy into [the room]1731-the room . [She]81-roxy had a pile of clean straw in the corner for a bed , some cheap but well - kept clothing was hanging on the wall , there was a tin lantern freckling the floor with little spots of light , and there were various soap - and - candle boxes scattered about , which served for chairs . [The two]1991-the two sat down . [Roxy]81-roxy said-- "[0-i] Now den , [I]0-i 'll tell [you]624-you straight off , en [I]0-i 'll begin to k'leck de money later on ; [I]0-i ai n't in no hurry . What does [you]624-you reckon [I]0-i 's gwine to tell [you]624-you ? " "[624-you] Well , [you]624-you -- [you]624-you -- oh , [Roxy]81-roxy , do n't make it too hard for [me]0-i ! Come right out and tell [me]0-i [you]81-roxy 've found out somehow what a shape [I]0-i 'm in on account of dissipation and foolishness . " "[0-i] Disposition en foolishness ! [No sir]625-no sir , dat ai n't it . [Dat]626-dat jist ai n't nothin' at all , ' longside o ' what [I]0-i knows . " [Tom]102-tom stared at [her]81-roxy , and said-- "[0-i] Why , [Roxy]81-roxy , what do [you]624-you mean ? " [She]81-roxy rose , and gloomed above [him]102-tom like a Fate . "[624-you] [I]0-i means dis -- en it 's de [Lord]627-lord 's truth . [You]624-you ai n't no more kin to [ole Marse Driscoll]141-ole marse driscoll den [I]0-i is!--dat 's what [I]0-i means ! " and [her]81-roxy eyes flamed with triumph . "[0-i] What ! " "[0-i] [Yassir]139-yassir , en dat ai n't all ! [You]624-you 's [a nigger!--bawn]628-a nigger!--bawn [a nigger]1452-a nigger en a slave!--en [you]624-you 's [a nigger en a slave dis minute]630-a nigger en a slave dis minute ; en if [I]0-i opens [my]0-i mouf ole [Marse Driscoll'll]142-marse driscoll'll sell [you]624-you down [de river]1447-de river befo ' [you]624-you is two days older den what [you]624-you is now ! " "[142-marse driscoll'll] It 's a thundering lie , [you]139-yassir [miserable old blatherskite]632-miserable old blatherskite ! " "[139-yassir] [It]633-it ai n't no lie , [nuther]617-nuther . It 's jes de truth , en nothin' but de truth , so he'p [me]0-i . [Yassir]139-yassir -- [you]624-you 's [[my]0-i son--]635-my son-- " "[139-yassir] [[You]139-yassir devil]636-you devil ! " "[139-yassir] En dat po ' boy dat [you]624-you 's be'n a - kickin ' en a - cuffin ' to - day is [[Percy Driscoll]82-percy driscoll 's son]637-percy driscoll 's son en [yo]638-yo ' marster-- " "[139-yassir] [You]139-yassir beast ! " "[139-yassir] En [his]639-his name 's [Tom Driscoll]83-tom , en [yo]638-yo ' name 's Valet [de Chambers]640-de chambers , en [you]624-you ai n't got no fambly name , [beca'se niggers]641-beca'se niggers do n't have [em]642-em ! " [Tom]83-tom sprang up and seized a billet of wood and raised raised it ; but [[his]83-tom mother]575-his mother only laughed at [him]83-tom , and said-- "[642-em] Set down , [[you]624-you pup]643-you pup ! Does [you]624-you think [you]624-you kin skyer [me]0-i ? [It]644-it ai n't in [you]624-you , nor [de]645-de likes of [you]624-you . [I]0-i reckon [you]624-you 'd shoot [me]0-i in de back , maybe , if [you]624-you got a chance , for dat 's jist [yo]624-you ' style -- [I]0-i knows [you]624-you , throo en throo -- but [I]0-i do n't mind gitt'n killed , beca'se all dis is down in writin ' en it 's in safe hands , too , en [de man]646-de man dat 's got it knows whah to look for [de right man]647-de right man when [I]0-i gits killed . Oh , bless [yo]624-you ' soul , if [you]624-you puts [[yo]624-you ' mother]648-yo ' mother up for as big a fool as [you]624-you is , [you]624-you 's pow'ful mistaken , [I]0-i kin tell [you]624-you ! Now den , [you]624-you set still en behave [yo'self]649-yo'self ; en do n't [you]624-you git up ag'in till [I]0-i tell [you]624-you ! " [Tom]83-tom fretted and chafed awhile in a whirlwind of disorganizing sensations and emotions , and finally said , with something like settled conviction-- "[0-i] The whole thing is moonshine ; now then , go ahead and do [your]624-you worst ; [I]0-i 'm done with [you]624-you . " [Roxy]81-roxy made no answer . [She]81-roxy took the lantern and started toward the door . [Tom]83-tom was in a cold panic in a moment . "[0-i] Come back , come back ! " [he]83-tom wailed . "[0-i] [I]0-i did n't mean it , [Roxy]81-roxy ; [I]0-i take it all back , and [I]0-i 'll never say it again ! Please come back , [Roxy]81-roxy ! " [The woman]1993-the woman stood a moment , then [she]1993-the woman said gravely : "[81-roxy] Dat 's one thing [you]0-i 's got to stop , [Valet de Chambers]95-chambers . [You]0-i ca n't call [me]0-i [Roxy]81-roxy , same as if [you]81-roxy was [[my]0-i equal]650-my equal . [Chillen]143-chillen do n't speak to [dey mammies]651-dey mammies like dat . [You]0-i 'll call [me]0-i [ma]517-ma or [mammy]1472-mammy , dat 's what [you]0-i 'll call [me]0-i -- leastways when [dey]654-dey ai n't [nobody]1501-nobody aroun ' . Say it ! " It cost [Tom]83-tom a struggle , but [he]83-tom got it out . "[0-i] Dat 's all right . Do n't [you]0-i ever forgit it ag'in , if [you]0-i knows what 's good for [you]0-i . Now den , [you]0-i has said [you]0-i would n't ever call it lies en moonshine ag'in . [I]0-i 'll tell [you]0-i dis , for a warnin ' : if [you]0-i ever does say it ag'in , it 's de las ' time [you]0-i 'll ever say it to [me]0-i ; [I]0-i 'll tramp as straight to [de Judge]656-de judge as [I]0-i kin walk , en tell [him]656-de judge who [you]0-i is , en prove it . Does [you]0-i b'lieve [me]0-i when [I]0-i says dat ? " "[0-i] Oh , " groaned [Tom]83-tom , "[0-i] [I]0-i more than believe it ; [I]0-i know it . " [Roxy]81-roxy knew [her]81-roxy conquest was complete . [She]81-roxy could have proved nothing to [anybody]1438-anybody , and [her]81-roxy threat about the writings was a lie ; but [she]81-roxy knew [the person [she]81-roxy was dealing with]1995-the person she was dealing with , and had made both statements without any doubt as to the effect they would produce . [She]81-roxy went and sat down on [her]81-roxy candle - box , and the pride and pomp of [her]81-roxy victorious attitude made it a throne . [She]81-roxy said-- "[0-i] Now den , [Chambers]95-chambers , [we]657-we 's gwine to talk business , en dey ai n't gwine to be no mo ' foolishness . In [de fust place]658-de fust place , [you]95-chambers gits fifty dollahs a month ; [you]95-chambers 's gwine to han ' over half of it to [[yo]659-yo ' ma]660-yo ' ma . Plank it out ! " But [Tom]83-tom had only six dollars in [the world]263-the world . [He]83-tom gave [her]81-roxy that , and promised to start fair on next month 's pension . "[95-chambers] [Chambers]95-chambers , how much is [you]95-chambers in debt ? " [Tom]83-tom shuddered , and said-- "[95-chambers] Nearly three hundred dollars . " "[95-chambers] How is [you]95-chambers gwine to pay it ? " [Tom]83-tom groaned out--"Oh[0-i] , [I]0-i do n't know ; do n't ask [me]0-i such awful questions . " But [she]81-roxy stuck to [her]81-roxy point until [she]81-roxy wearied a confession out of [him]83-tom : [he]83-tom had been prowling about in disguise , stealing small valuables from [private houses]1997-private houses ; in fact , [he]83-tom made a good deal of a raid on [[his]83-tom fellow - villagers]1998-his fellow - villagers a fortnight before , when [he]83-tom was supposed to be in [St. Louis]8-st. louis ; but [he]83-tom doubted if [he]83-tom had sent away enough stuff to realize the required amount , and was afraid to make a further venture in the present excited state of [the town]289-the town . [[His]83-tom mother]575-his mother approved of [his]83-tom conduct , and offered to help , but this frightened [him]83-tom . [He]83-tom tremblingly ventured to say that if [she]81-roxy would retire from [the town]289-the town [he]83-tom should feel better and safer , and could hold [his]83-tom head higher -- and was going on to make an argument , but [she]81-roxy interrupted and surprised [him]83-tom pleasantly by saying [she]81-roxy was ready ; it did n't make any difference to [her]81-roxy where [she]81-roxy stayed , so that [she]81-roxy got [her]81-roxy share of the pension regularly . [She]81-roxy said [she]81-roxy would not go far , and would call at [the haunted house]1978-the haunted house once a month for [her]81-roxy money . Then [she]81-roxy said-- "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't hate [you]661-you so much now , but [I]0-i 've hated [you]661-you a many a year -- and [anybody]1438-anybody would . Did n't [I]0-i change [you]661-you off , [en]663-en give [you]661-you a good fambly en a good name , en made [you]661-you [a white gen'l'man]664-a white gen'l'man en rich , wid store clothes on -- en what did [I]0-i git for it ? [You]661-you despised [me]0-i all de time , [en]663-en was al'ays sayin ' mean hard things to [me]0-i befo ' [folks]513-folks , [en]663-en would n't ever let [me]0-i forgit [I]0-i 's [a nigger]1452-a nigger -- en -- en------ " [She]661-you fell to sobbing , and broke down . [Tom]83-tom said--"But[661-you] [you]661-you know [I]0-i did n't know [you]661-you were [[my]0-i mother]667-my mother ; and besides-- " "[663-en] Well , [nemmine 'bout dat]668-nemmine 'bout dat , now ; let it go . [I]0-i 's gwine to fo'git it . " Then [she]661-you added fiercely , "[663-en] [En]663-en do n't ever make [me]0-i remember it ag'in , or [you]661-you 'll be sorry , [I]0-i tell [you]661-you . " When [they]2003-they were parting , [Tom]83-tom said , in the most persuasive way [he]83-tom could command-- "[0-i] [Ma]517-ma , would [you]517-ma mind telling [me]0-i who was [[my]0-i father]531-my father ? " [He]83-tom had supposed [he]83-tom was asking an embarrassing question . [He]83-tom was mistaken . [Roxy]81-roxy drew [herself]81-roxy up with a proud toss of [her]81-roxy head , and said-- "[517-ma] Does [I]0-i mine tellin ' [you]661-you ? No , [dat]671-dat [I]0-i do n't ! [You]661-you ai n't got no ' casion to be shame ' o ' [[yo]661-you ' father]672-yo ' father , [I]0-i kin tell [you]661-you . [He]672-yo ' father wuz de highest quality in [dis whole town]673-dis whole town -- ole Virginny stock . Fust famblies , [he]672-yo ' father wuz . [Jes]674-jes as good stock as [de Driscolls]144-de driscolls en [de Howards]145-de howards , de bes ' day [dey]675-dey ever seed . " [She]2004-her put on a little prouder air , if possible , and added impressively : "[661-you] Does [you]661-you ' member [Cunnel Cecil Burleigh Essex]146-cunnel cecil burleigh essex , dat died de same year [yo]661-you ' young Marse [Tom Driscoll]83-tom 's pappy died , en all de Masons en [Odd Fellers en Churches]676-odd fellers en churches turned out en give [him]672-yo ' father [de bigges]147-de bigges ' funeral [dis town]499-dis town ever seed ? Dat 's [de man]646-de man . " Under the inspiration of [her]2004-her soaring complacency the departed graces of [her]2004-her earlier days returned to [her]2004-her , and [her]2004-her bearing took to itself a dignity and state that might have passed for queenly if [her]2004-her surroundings had been a little more in keeping with it . "[646-de man] [Dey]675-dey ai n't another nigger in [dis town]499-dis town dat 's as high - bawn as [you]661-you is . Now den , go ' long ! En jes [you]661-you hold [yo]661-you ' head up as high as [you]661-you want to -- [you]661-you has de right , en dat [I]0-i kin swah . " CHAPTER X. The Nymph Revealed . [All]2005-all say , "[661-you] How hard it is that [we]680-we have to die"--a strange complaint to come from the mouths of [people who have had to live.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar]2006-people who have had to live.--pudd'nhead wilson 's calendar . When angry , count four ; when very angry , swear.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar . Every now and then , after [Tom]83-tom went to bed , [he]83-tom had sudden wakings out of [his]83-tom sleep , and [his]83-tom first thought was , "[661-you] Oh , joy , it was all a dream ! " Then [he]83-tom laid [himself]83-tom heavily down again , with a groan and the muttered words , "[1452-a nigger] [A nigger]1452-a nigger ! [I]0-i am [a nigger]1452-a nigger ! Oh , [I]0-i wish [I]0-i was dead ! " [He]83-tom woke at dawn with one more repetition of this horror , and then [he]83-tom resolved to meddle no more with that treacherous sleep . [He]83-tom began to think . Sufficiently bitter thinkings [they]2007-they were . [They]2007-they wandered along something after this fashion : "[0-i] Why were [niggers]1468-niggers and [whites]684-whites made ? What crime did [the uncreated first nigger]685-the uncreated first nigger commit that the curse of birth was decreed for [him]685-the uncreated first nigger ? And why is this awful difference made between white and black ? ... How hard [the nigger]686-the nigger 's fate seems , this morning!--yet until last night such a thought never entered [my]0-i head .
