[He]86-wilson arranged [his]86-wilson records on the table before [him]86-wilson , and said-- " [I]86-wilson beg the indulgence of [the court]2768-the court while [I]86-wilson make a few remarks in explanation of some evidence which [I]86-wilson am about to introduce , and which [I]86-wilson shall presently ask to be allowed to verify under oath on the witness stand . [Every human being]2828-every human being carries with [him]2828-every human being from [his]2828-every human being cradle to [his]2828-every human being grave certain physical marks which do not change their character , and by which [he]2828-every human being can always be identified -- and that without shade of doubt or question . These marks are [his]2828-every human being signature , [his]2828-every human being physiological autograph , so to speak , and this autograph can not be counterfeited , nor can [he]2828-every human being disguise it or hide it away , nor can it become illegible by the wear and mutations of time . This signature is not [his]2828-every human being face -- age can change that beyond recognition ; it is not [his]2828-every human being hair , for that can fall out ; it is not [his]2828-every human being height , for duplicates of that exist ; it is not [his]2828-every human being form , for duplicates of that exist also , whereas this signature is [each man]2829-each man 's very own -- there is no duplicate of it among [the swarming populations of [the globe]2213-the globe]2830-the swarming populations of the globe ! [ [The audience]1950-the audience were interested once more . ] "[86-wilson] This autograph consists of the delicate lines or corrugations with which Nature marks the insides of the hands and the soles of the feet . If [you]1324-you will look at the balls of [your]1324-you fingers,--you that have very sharp eyesight,--you will observe that these dainty curving lines lie close together , like those that indicate the borders of [oceans]1325-oceans in maps , and that they form various clearly defined patterns , such as arches , circles , long curves , whorls , etc . , and that these patterns differ on the different fingers . [ [Every man in [the room]1731-the room]1326-every man in the room had [his]1326-every man in the room hand up to the light , now , and [his]1326-every man in the room head canted to one side , and was minutely scrutinizing the balls of [his]1326-every man in the room fingers ; there were whispered ejaculations of ' Why , it 's so -- [I]0-i never noticed that before ! ' ] The patterns on the right hand are not the same as those on the left . [ Ejaculations of ' Why , that 's so , too ! ' ] Taken finger for finger , [your]1324-you patterns differ from [[your]1324-you neighbor]1328-your neighbor 's . [ Comparisons were made all over [the house]247-the house -- even [the judge]315-the judge and [jury]1331-jury were absorbed in this curious work . ] The patterns of [a twin]1332-a twin 's right hand are not the same as those on [his]1332-a twin left . [One twin]706-one twin 's patterns are never the same as [his]1332-a twin fellow - twin 's patterns -- [the jury]2629-the jury will find that the patterns upon the finger - balls of [the accused]2766-the accused follow this rule . [ An examination of [the twins]1762-the twins ' hands was begun at once . ] [You]1324-you have often heard of [twins who were so exactly alike]1337-twins who were so exactly alike that when dressed alike [[their]1337-twins who were so exactly alike own parents]1338-their own parents could not tell [them]1337-twins who were so exactly alike apart . Yet there was never [a twin born into [this world]1703-this world that did not carry from birth to death a sure identifier in this mysterious and marvelous natal autograph]1339-a twin born into this world that did not carry from birth to death a sure identifier in this mysterious and marvelous natal autograph . That once known to [you]1324-you , [[his]1332-a twin fellow - twin]1341-his fellow - twin could never personate [him]1332-a twin and deceive [you]1324-you . " [Wilson]86-wilson stopped and stood silent . Inattention dies a quick and sure death when [a speaker]2833-a speaker does that . The stillness gives warning that something is coming . All palms and finger - balls went down , now , all slouching forms straightened , all heads came up , all eyes were fastened upon [Wilson]86-wilson 's face . [He]86-wilson waited yet one , two , three moments , to let [his]86-wilson pause complete and perfect its spell upon [the house]247-the house ; then , when through the profound hush [he]86-wilson could hear the ticking of the clock on the wall , [he]86-wilson put out [his]86-wilson hand and took the Indian knife by the blade and held it aloft where all could see the sinister spots upon its ivory handle ; then [he]86-wilson said , in a level and passionless voice-- "[2603-the assassin] Upon [this haft]1342-this haft stands [the assassin]2603-the assassin 's natal autograph , written in the blood of [that helpless and unoffending old man who loved [you]1324-you and whom [you]1324-you all loved]1344-that helpless and unoffending old man who loved you and whom you all loved . There is but [one man in [the whole earth]1346-the whole earth]1345-one man in the whole earth whose hand can duplicate that crimson sign,"--he paused and raised [his]86-wilson eyes to the pendulum swinging back and forth,--"and[100-god] please [God]100-god [we]1347-we will produce [that man]2328-that man in [this room]1724-this room before the clock strikes noon ! " Stunned , distraught , unconscious of [its]247-the house own movement , [the house]247-the house half rose , as if expecting to see [the murderer]2836-the murderer appear at the door , and a breeze of muttered ejaculations swept [the place]2456-the place . "[1347-we] Order in the court!--sit down ! " This from [the sheriff]2614-the sheriff . [He]2614-the sheriff was obeyed , and quiet reigned again . [Wilson]86-wilson stole a glance at [Tom]83-tom , and said to [himself]86-wilson , "[2328-that man] [He]2328-that man is flying signals of distress , now ; even people who despise [him]2328-that man are pitying [him]2328-that man ; [they]1350-they think this is a hard ordeal for [a young fellow who has lost [[his]2328-that man benefactor]2568-his benefactor by so cruel a stroke -- and [they]1350-they are right]1351-a young fellow who has lost his benefactor by so cruel a stroke -- and they are right . " [He]86-wilson resumed [his]86-wilson speech : "[1350-they] For more than twenty years [I]0-i have amused [my]0-i compulsory leisure with collecting these curious physical signatures in [this town]518-this town . At [[my]0-i house]1354-my house [I]0-i have hundreds upon hundreds of them . Each and every one is labelled with name and date ; not labelled the next day or even the next hour , but in the very minute that the impression was taken . When [I]0-i go upon the witness stand [I]0-i will repeat under oath the things which [I]0-i am now saying . [I]0-i have the finger - prints of [the court]2768-the court , [the sheriff]2614-the sheriff , and [every member of the jury]1357-every member of the jury . There is hardly [a person in [this room]1724-this room]1358-a person in this room , white or black , whose natal signature [I]0-i can not produce , and not one of [them]1350-they can so disguise [himself]1358-a person in this room that [I]0-i can not pick [him]1358-a person in this room out from [a multitude of [his]1358-a person in this room fellow - creatures]1360-a multitude of his fellow - creatures and unerringly identify [him]1358-a person in this room by [his]1358-a person in this room hands . And if [he]1358-a person in this room and [I]0-i should live to be a hundred [I]0-i could still do it . [ The interest of [the audience]1950-the audience was steadily deepening , now . ] " [I]1362-i have studied some of these signatures so much that [I]1362-i know them as well as [the bank cashier]2839-the bank cashier knows the autograph of [[his]2839-the bank cashier oldest customer]2840-his oldest customer . While [I]1362-i turn [my]1362-i back now , [I]1362-i beg that [several persons]2841-several persons will be so good as to pass [their]2841-several persons fingers through [their]2841-several persons hair , and then press them upon one of the panes of the window near [the jury]2629-the jury , and that among [them]2841-several persons [the accused]2766-the accused may set [their]2766-the accused finger - marks . Also , [I]1362-i beg that [these experimenters]2844-these experimenters , or [others]1566-others , will set [their]2844-these experimenters finger - marks upon another pane , and add again the marks of [the accused]2766-the accused , but not placing them in the same order or relation to the other signatures as before -- for , by one chance in a million , [a person]2031-a person might happen upon the right marks by pure guess - work once , therefore [I]1362-i wish to be tested twice . "[1362-i] [He]1362-i turned [his]1362-i back , and the two panes were quickly covered with delicately - lined oval spots , but visible only to [such persons]1363-such persons as could get a dark background for [them]1363-such persons -- the foliage of a tree , outside , for instance . Then , upon call , [Wilson]86-wilson went to the window , made [his]86-wilson examination , and said-- " This is [Count Luigi]119-luigi 's right hand ; this one , three signatures below , is [his]119-luigi left . Here is [Count Angelo]120-angelo 's right ; down here is [his]119-luigi left . Now for the other pane : here and here are [Count Luigi]119-luigi 's , here and here are [[his]119-luigi brother]1537-his brother 's . "[1362-i] [He]1362-i faced about . " Am [I]86-wilson right ? "[86-wilson] A deafening explosion of applause was the answer . [The Bench]1364-the bench said-- " This certainly approaches the miraculous ! "[86-wilson] [Wilson]86-wilson turned to the window again and remarked , pointing with [his]86-wilson finger-- " This is the signature of [Mr. Justice Robinson]123-justice robinson . [ Applause . ] This , of [Constable Blake]175-blake . [ Applause . ] This , of [John Mason]207-john mason , [juryman]2849-juryman . [ Applause . ] This , of [the sheriff]2614-the sheriff . [ Applause . ] [I]1362-i can not name [the others]438-the others , but [I]1362-i have [them]438-the others all at [home]1541-home , named and dated , and could identify [them]438-the others all by [my]1362-i finger - print records . "[1362-i] [He]1362-i moved to [[his]1362-i place]1365-his place through a storm of applause -- which [the sheriff]2614-the sheriff stopped , and also made [the people]332-the people sit down , for [they]332-the people were all standing and struggling to see , of course . [Court]787-court , [jury]1331-jury , [sheriff]1370-sheriff , and [everybody]367-everybody had been too absorbed in observing [Wilson]86-wilson 's performance to attend to [the audience]1950-the audience earlier . " Now , then , "[86-wilson] said [Wilson]86-wilson , " [I]86-wilson have here the natal autographs of [two children]2853-two children -- thrown up to ten times the natural size by the pantograph , so that [any one who can see at all]2854-any one who can see at all can tell the markings apart at a glance . [We]2855-we will call [the children A and B.]2856-the children a and b. Here are A 's finger - marks , taken at the age of five months . Here they are again , taken at seven months . [ [Tom]83-tom started . ] [They]2853-two children are alike , [you]1374-you see . Here are B 's at five months , and also at seven months . [They]2853-two children , too , exactly copy each other , but the patterns are quite different from A 's , [you]1374-you observe . [I]86-wilson shall refer to these again presently , but [we]2855-we will turn them face down , now . "[86-wilson] Here , thrown up ten sizes , are the natal autographs of [the two persons who are here before [you]1374-you accused of murdering [Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll]1373-the two persons who are here before you accused of murdering judge driscoll . [I]0-i made these pantograph copies last night , and will so swear when [I]0-i go upon the witness stand . [I]0-i ask [the jury]2629-the jury to compare them with the finger - marks of [the accused upon the window panes]1376-the accused upon the window panes , and tell [the court]2768-the court if they are the same . " [He]0-i passed a powerful magnifying - glass to [the foreman]2857-the foreman . [One juryman]2858-one juryman after [another]361-another took the cardboard and the glass and made the comparison . Then [the foreman]2857-the foreman said to [the judge--]2391-the judge-- "[1378-your honor] [[Your]1374-you honor]1378-your honor , [we]1379-we are all agreed that they are identical . " [Wilson]86-wilson said to the foreman-- "[1378-your honor] Please turn that cardboard face down , and take this one , and compare it searchingly , by [the magnifier]1380-the magnifier , with the fatal signature upon the knife - handle , and report [your]1374-you finding to [the court]2768-the court . " Again [the jury]2629-the jury made minute examinations , and again reported-- "[1379-we] [We]1379-we find them to be exactly identical , [[your]1374-you honor]1378-your honor . " [Wilson]86-wilson turned toward [the counsel for the prosecution]2863-the counsel for the prosecution , and there was a clearly recognizable note of warning in [his]86-wilson voice when [he]86-wilson said-- "[1379-we] May it please [the court]2768-the court , [the State]2731-the state has claimed , strenuously and persistently , that the blood - stained finger - prints upon that knife - handle were left there by [the assassin of [Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll]1385-the assassin of judge driscoll . [You]1374-you have heard [us]1379-we grant that claim , and welcome it . " [He]86-wilson turned to [the jury]2629-the jury : "[1374-you] Compare the finger - prints of [the accused]2766-the accused with the finger - prints left by [the assassin]2603-the assassin -- and report . " The comparison began . As it proceeded , all movement and all sound ceased , and the deep silence of an absorbed and waiting suspense settled upon [the house]247-the house ; and when at last the words came-- "[1374-you] They do not even resemble , " a thunder - crash of applause followed and [the house]247-the house sprang to its feet , but was quickly repressed by official force and brought to order again . [Tom]83-tom was altering [his]83-tom position every few minutes , now , but none of [his]83-tom changes brought repose nor any small trifle of comfort . When [the house]247-the house 's attention was become fixed once more , [Wilson]86-wilson said gravely , indicating [the twins]1762-the twins with a gesture-- "[1374-you] [These men]1292-these men are innocent -- [I]0-i have no further concern with [them]1292-these men . [ Another outbreak of applause began , but was promptly checked . ] [We]1379-we will now proceed to find [the guilty]1389-the guilty . [ [Tom]83-tom 's eyes were starting from their sockets -- yes , it was a cruel day for [the bereaved youth]1390-the bereaved youth , [everybody]367-everybody thought . ] [We]1379-we will return to the infant autographs of A and B. [I]0-i will ask [the jury]2629-the jury to take these large pantograph facsimilies of A 's marked five months and seven months . Do [they]1292-these men tally ? " [The foreman]2857-the foreman responded-- "[1292-these men] Perfectly . " "[2629-the jury] Now examine this pantograph , taken at eight months , and also marked A. Does it tally with the other two ? " The surprised response was-- "[2629-the jury] No -- [they]1292-these men differ widely ! " "[0-i] [You]0-i are quite right . Now take these two pantographs of B 's autograph , marked five months and seven months . Do [they]1292-these men tally with each other ? " "[1292-these men] Yes -- perfectly . " "[1292-these men] Take this third pantograph marked B , eight months . Does it tally with [B]208-b 's other two ? " "[208-b] By no means ! " "[208-b] Do [you]0-i know how to account for those strange discrepancies ? [I]0-i will tell [you]0-i . For a purpose unknown to [us]1379-we , but probably a selfish one , [somebody]358-somebody changed [those children in the cradle]1394-those children in the cradle . " This produced a vast sensation , naturally ; [Roxana]81-roxy was astonished at this admirable guess , but not disturbed by it . To guess the exchange was one thing , to guess who did it quite another . [Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson could do wonderful things , no doubt , but [he]86-wilson could n't do impossible ones . Safe ? [She]81-roxy was perfectly safe . [She]81-roxy smiled privately . "[358-somebody] Between the ages of seven months and eight months [those children]1395-those children were changed in the cradle"--he made one of [his]86-wilson effect - collecting pauses , and added--"and[1396-the person who did it] [the person who did it]1396-the person who did it is in [this house]1397-this house ! " [Roxy]81-roxy 's pulses stood still ! [The house]247-the house was thrilled as with an electric shock , and [the people]332-the people half rose as if to seek a glimpse of [the person who had made that exchange]2872-the person who had made that exchange . [Tom]83-tom was growing limp ; the life seemed oozing out of [him]83-tom . [Wilson]86-wilson resumed : "[209-a] [A]209-a was put into [[B]208-b 's cradle]1398-b 's cradle in [the nursery]1399-the nursery ; [B]208-b was transferred to [the kitchen]1400-the kitchen and became [a negro]405-a negro and [a slave]408-a slave , [ Sensation -- confusion of angry ejaculations]--but within a quarter of an hour [he]208-b will stand before [you]1403-you white and free ! [ Burst of applause , checked by [the officers]1916-the officers . ] From seven months onward until now , [A]209-a has still been [a usurper]1405-a usurper , and in [my]0-i finger - record [he]209-a bears [B]208-b 's name . Here is [his]209-a pantograph at the age of twelve . Compare it with [the assassin]2603-the assassin 's signature upon the knife - handle . Do [they]1407-they tally ? " [The foreman]2857-the foreman answered-- "[1407-they] To the minutest detail ! " [Wilson]86-wilson said , solemnly-- "[1407-they] [The murderer of [[your]1403-you friend]1409-your friend and [mine]0-i]1408-the murderer of your friend and mine -- [York Driscoll]83-tom of the generous hand and the kindly spirit -- sits in among [you]1403-you . [Valet de Chambre]94-valet de chambre , [negro]1410-negro and slave,--falsely called [Thomas à Becket Driscoll,--make]210-tom upon the window the finger - prints that will hang [you]1403-you ! " [Tom]210-tom turned [his]210-tom ashen face imploring toward [the speaker]1301-the speaker , made some impotent movements with [his]210-tom white lips , then slid limp and lifeless to the floor . [Wilson]86-wilson broke the awed silence with the words-- "[210-tom] There is no need . [He]209-a has confessed . " [Roxy]81-roxy flung [herself]81-roxy upon [her]81-roxy knees , covered [her]81-roxy face with [her]81-roxy hands , and out through [her]81-roxy sobs the words struggled-- "[209-a] [De Lord]211-de lord have mercy on [me]0-i , po ' misable sinner dat [I]0-i is ! " The clock struck twelve . [The court]2768-the court rose ; [the new prisoner]2876-the new prisoner , handcuffed , was removed . Conclusion It is often the case that [the man who ca n't tell a lie]2877-the man who ca n't tell a lie thinks [he]2877-the man who ca n't tell a lie is [the best judge of one.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar]2878-the best judge of one.--pudd'nhead wilson 's calendar . October 12 , the Discovery . It was wonderful to find [America]50-america , but it would have been more wonderful to miss it.--Pudd'nhead [Wilson]86-wilson 's Calendar . [The town]289-the town sat up all night to discuss the amazing events of the day and swap guesses as to when [Tom]210-tom 's trial would begin . [Troop]2880-troop after [troop of [citizens]2882-citizens]2881-troop of citizens came to serenade [Wilson]86-wilson , and require a speech , and shout [themselves]2881-troop of citizens hoarse over every sentence that fell from [his]86-wilson lips -- for all [his]86-wilson sentences were golden , now , all were marvelous . [His]86-wilson long fight against hard luck and prejudice was ended ; [he]86-wilson was [a made man]2354-a made man for good . And as each of [these roaring gangs of [enthusiasts]2885-enthusiasts]2884-these roaring gangs of enthusiasts marched away , [some remorseful member of it]2886-some remorseful member of it was quite sure to raise [his]2886-some remorseful member of it voice and say-- "[211-de lord] And this is [the man the likes of [us]1412-us]1411-the man the likes of us have called [a pudd'nhead]1441-a pudd'nhead for more than twenty years . [He]1411-the man the likes of us has resigned from that position , [friends]1786-friends . " "[1411-the man the likes of us] Yes , but it is n't vacant -- [we're]1412-us elected . " [The twins]1762-the twins were [heroes of romance]2888-heroes of romance , now , and with rehabilitated reputations . But [they]1762-the twins were weary of Western adventure , and straightway retired to [Europe]32-europe . [Roxy]81-roxy 's heart was broken . [The young fellow upon whom [she]81-roxy had inflicted twenty - three years of slavery]2889-the young fellow upon whom she had inflicted twenty - three years of slavery continued [the false heir]1603-the false heir 's pension of thirty - five dollars a month to [her]81-roxy , but [her]81-roxy hurts were too deep for money to heal ; the spirit in [her]81-roxy eye was quenched , [her]81-roxy martial bearing departed with it , and the voice of [her]81-roxy laughter ceased in [the land]2210-the land . In [[her]81-roxy church]2892-her church and its affairs [she]81-roxy found [her]81-roxy only solace . [The real heir]1547-the real heir suddenly found [himself]1547-the real heir rich and free , but in a most embarrassing situation . [He]1547-the real heir could neither read nor write , and [his]1547-the real heir speech was the basest dialect of [the negro quarter]2894-the negro quarter . [His]1547-the real heir gait , [his]1547-the real heir attitudes , [his]1547-the real heir gestures , [his]1547-the real heir bearing , [his]1547-the real heir laugh -- all were vulgar and uncouth ; [his]1547-the real heir manners were the manners of [a slave]408-a slave . Money and fine clothes could not mend these defects or cover them up ; they only made [them]2896-them the more glaring and the more pathetic . [The poor fellow]2897-the poor fellow could not endure the terrors of [[the white man]2898-the white man 's parlor]2899-the white man 's parlor , and felt at [home]1541-home and at peace nowhere but in [the kitchen]1400-the kitchen . [The family pew]2902-the family pew was a misery to [him]2897-the poor fellow , yet [he]2897-the poor fellow could nevermore enter into [the solacing refuge of [the "[210-tom] nigger gallery"--that]2904-the " nigger gallery"--that]2903-the solacing refuge of the " nigger gallery"--that was closed to [him]2897-the poor fellow for good and all . But [we]2905-we can not follow [his]2897-the poor fellow curious fate further -- that would be a long story . [The false heir]1603-the false heir made a full confession and was sentenced to imprisonment for life . But now a complication came up . [The Percy Driscoll estate]2907-the percy driscoll estate was in such a crippled shape when [its owner]2457-its owner died that [it]2907-the percy driscoll estate could pay only sixty per cent . of [its]2907-the percy driscoll estate great indebtedness , and was settled at that rate . But [the creditors]2909-the creditors came forward , now , and complained that inasmuch as through an error for which [they]2909-the creditors were in no way to blame [the false heir]1603-the false heir was not inventoried at the time with the rest of [the property]2911-the property , great wrong and loss had thereby been inflicted upon [them]2909-the creditors . [They]2909-the creditors rightly claimed that "[210-tom] [Tom]210-tom " was lawfully [their]2909-the creditors property and had been so for eight years ; that [they]2909-the creditors had already lost sufficiently in being deprived of [his]210-tom services during that long period , and ought not to be required to add anything to that loss ; that if [he]210-tom had been delivered up to [them]2909-the creditors in the first place , [they]2909-the creditors would have sold [him]210-tom and [he]210-tom could not have murdered [Judge Driscoll]88-judge driscoll ; therefore it was not [he]210-tom that had really committed the murder , the guilt lay with the erroneous inventory . [Everybody]367-everybody saw that there was reason in this . [Everybody]367-everybody granted that if "[210-tom] [Tom]210-tom " were white and free it would be unquestionably right to punish [him]210-tom -- it would be no loss to [anybody]1438-anybody ; but to shut up [a valuable slave]2915-a valuable slave for life -- that was quite another matter . As soon as [the Governor]2916-the governor understood the case , [he]2916-the governor pardoned [Tom]210-tom at once , and [the creditors]2909-the creditors sold [him]210-tom down [the river]269-the river . Transcriber 's Notes Introduction : 1 . Background . Welcome to [Project Gutenberg]212-project gutenberg 's presentation of [Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson . [The Italian twins]2919-the italian twins in this novel , [Luigi]119-luigi and [Angelo]120-angelo , were inspired by [a real pair of Italian conjoined twins who toured [America]50-america in the 1890s]2920-a real pair of italian conjoined twins who toured america in the 1890s . [These]2920-a real pair of italian conjoined twins who toured america in the 1890s were [Giacomo]213-giacomo and [Giovanni Battista Tocci]214-giovanni battista tocci . [Homer Plessy]215-homer plessy was arrested for sitting in [a whites - only passenger car]2921-a whites - only passenger car on June 7 , 1892 , and one month later [he]215-homer plessy stood before [Judge John Howard Ferguson]216-judge john howard ferguson to plead [his]215-homer plessy case . [Plessy]215-homer plessy was an octaroon who could easily "[210-tom] pass white . " Four years later , [the Supreme Court]2922-the supreme court condoned "[210-tom] Separate but Equal " laws in the famous [Plessy vs. Ferguson]217-plessy vs. ferguson case , which affirmed the decision of [Justice Ferguson]218-justice ferguson in [local court]2923-local court . These events in 1892 unfolded as [Twain]74-twain wrote this story , and changed the tale that [he]74-twain ended up telling . [Arthur Conan Doyle]219-arthur conan doyle released [his]219-arthur conan doyle best - selling collection of short stories , The Adventures of [Sherlock Holmes]220-sherlock holmes , on October 14 , 1892 . The stories had already appeared in The Strand Magazine , one each month , from July 1891 to June 1892 . [Holmes]220-sherlock holmes inspired [Twain]74-twain to add a component of forensics to this story . 2 . [Dialect]221-dialect . The soliloquies and conversations in the novel follow some general rules . [Twain]74-twain introduced some variations in the spelling of dialect , and sometimes the sound of dialect , but the end meaning seems to be the same thing . Below is a table of some of these words , and alternatives found in the text : Dialect used in [Pudd'nhead Wilson English Dialect]65-pudd'nhead wilson english dialect , Alternative , Another and en against agin , ag'in , ag'in ' because ' ca'se going gwine , gwyne more mo ' that dat the de then den there dere , dah these dese [they]2924-they dey , [deh]2925-deh this dis was ' uz with wid where whah The above table was presented as a foundation which played into the decision to make some emendations , below , that were not authorized by [Twain]74-twain in 1899 . One curious notation is that there was sometimes pronounced dere , but also dah . Along the same lines , they most often became dey , but in one case , deh . 3 . This version . [Our]2926-we version is based on the 1894 publication of this novel in [Hartford]66-hartford . This was [Twain]74-twain 's original American release of the novel in book form . A scanned copy of this book is available through Hathitrust . The book contained some spaces in contractions : [I]210-tom 'll , dat 'll , had n't , could n't , dis 'll , ' t ai n't / t ai n't , and [dey]2927-dey 'll are some examples . These spaces were not retained in [our]2926-we transcription , and are not identified . [We]2926-we did make a few other emendations . These emendations were checked with the 1899 version of [Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson published by Harper & amp ; Brothers . 4 . Notes on emendations . The errors on Page 233 and Page 288 , were not changed in the 1899 book , so the case for making those changes may be found in the Detailed Notes section . The remaining errors were corrected in the 1899 publication , presumably authorized by [Twain]74-twain , who essentially made the case for those emendations . In the HTML version of this e - book , [you]2928-you can place [your]2928-you cursor over the faint silver dotted lines below the changed text to discover the original text . The Detailed Notes section of these notes describe these emendations . 5 . Other versions . Please note that many print versions of [Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson include the phrase ' spelling and usage have been brought into conformity with modern usage , ' and [editors]2929-editors have been liberal with [their]2929-editors renditions of [Twain]74-twain 's story . 6 . Detailed notes . The Detailed Notes Section also includes issues that have come up during transcription . One common issue is that words are sometimes split into two lines for spacing purposes in the original text . These words are hyphenated in the physical book , but there is a question sometimes as to whether the hyphen should be retained in transcription . The reasons behind some of these decisions are itemized . Production Notes Section : 1 . Chapter Titles . The Chapter Titles , such as Doom in Chapter XXI . , were not part of [Twain]74-twain 's book . They remain from another version of this book . The chapter titles are used in PG 's Mark Twain index , so [we]2926-we have retained them . 2 . [The Author]2086-the author 's Note . [The Author]2086-the author 's Note to [Those Extraordinary Twins]222-those extraordinary twins is actually [the author]2086-the author 's introduction to the novella , [Those Extraordinary Twins]222-those extraordinary twins . [Twain]74-twain originally produced this book with two parts : [Pudd'nhead Wilson]86-wilson and [Those Extraordinary Twins]222-those extraordinary twins . [Project Gutenberg]212-project gutenberg offers both stories , so [we]2926-we present [the Author]2086-the author 's Note as the Introduction to [Those Extraordinary Twins]222-those extraordinary twins , as [Twain]74-twain intended . If [you]2934-you want to read [the Author]2086-the author 's Note , please visit the Introduction of [our]2926-we production of the novella , [Those Extraordinary Twins]222-those extraordinary twins . Detailed Notes Section : Chapter 1 . On Page 19 , [barber - shop]2936-barber - shop was hyphenated between two lines for spacing . The 1899 Harper & amp ; Brothers version used "[210-tom] [barber shop]1415-barber shop " in this spot . Even though [barber - shop]2936-barber - shop can not be transcribed as such , the assumption is that the 1894 version put in the hyphen by mistake . [We]2926-we transcribed the word [barber shop]1415-barber shop . Chapter 2 . On Page 34 , changed ca'se to ' ca'se , used as dialect for because , in the clause : "[1416-mine] but dat 's ca'se it 's [mine]1416-mine . " [The author]2086-the author used ' ca'se eighteen other times as dialect for because , and did not use ca'se again . Chapter 3 . On Page 43 , insert missing period after tomb . Chapter 6 . On Page 81 , add a comma after door : "[1762-the twins] [The twins]1762-the twins took a position near the door [the widow]1721-the widow stood at [Luigi]119-luigi 's side , [Rowena]118-rowena stood beside [Angelo]120-angelo , ... " Chapter 7 . On Page 88 , add a period after fault in the sentence : [The Judge]315-the judge laid [himself]315-the judge out hospitably to make [them]1762-the twins have a good time , and if there was a defect anywhere it was not [his]315-the judge fault . Chapter 9 . On Page 114 , there is a word missing before the semicolon in the clause : [Tom]210-tom sprang up and seized a billet of wood and raised ; the 1899 Harper & amp ; Brothers version provided the missing word , "[1721-the widow] it . " Chapter 11 . On Page 131 , change dicision to decision in the clause : [Luigi]119-luigi reserved [his]119-luigi dicision . On Page 133 , change comma to a period after years in the sentence : "[1721-the widow] [I]0-i never got a chance to try [my]0-i hand at it , and [I]0-i may never get a chance ; and yet if [I]0-i ever do get it [I]0-i shall be found ready , for [I]0-i have kept up [my]0-i law - studies all these years , " On Page 149 , Correct spelling of [Cappello]223-cappello to [Capello]119-luigi . On Page 167 , Change ' to "[1721-the widow] in the sentence : " Why , [[my]1721-the widow boy]808-my boy , [you]808-my boy look desolate . Do n't take it so hard . Try and forget [you]808-my boy have been kicked . ' On Page 176 , ship - shape was hyphenated and split between two lines for spacing . The 1899 Harper & amp ; [Brothers version of the novel]2943-brothers version of the novel used shipshape , and so will [we]2944-we . Chapter 14 . On Page 182 , changed period after hatching to question mark in the sentence : What could be hatching . On Page 184 , remove comma after sha'n't , in the clause : but if [he]808-my boy does n't , [I]1721-the widow sha'n't , let on . On Page 189 , low - down is hyphenated and split between two lines for spacing . On Page 188 , low - down is spelled with a hyphen , and on pages 241 and 243 low - downest is also hyphenated . There is no occurrence of lowdown . [We]2944-we transcribed low - down with a hyphen : like a ornery low - down hound ! Chapter 16 . On Page 216 , Changed ? to ! in the sentence : En keep on sayin ' it ? Chapter 18 . On Page 229 , Changed ' against to against in the clause : with fury ' against [[the planter]2415-the planter 's wife]2490-the planter 's wife . On Page 233 , Changed de to den in the clause "[1721-the widow] en de good gracious [me]0-i . " [The author]2086-the author always used den for then , except in this case . [De]211-de lord is dialect for the . [Twain]74-twain did not correct this in the 1899 Harper & amp ; Brothers version of the novel , but den makes more sense then de . [Roxy]81-roxy was floating on [the river]269-the river , and then [she]81-roxy cried good gracious [me]1721-the widow , because [she]81-roxy spotted the Grand Mogul . Changed day to dey in two places . The novel used dey as dialect for [they]2949-they regularly , and almost consistently , except in two cases . Both cases were presumed errata : • On Page 232 , en day warn't gwine to hurry • On Page 229 , en day knows how to whale ['em]2950-'em , too . Chapter 19 . On Page 253 , [back - yard]2951-back - yard is hyphenated and split between two lines for spacing . The 1899 Harper & amp ; Brothers version of the novel used [back - yard]2951-back - yard , and so will [we]2944-we . Chapter 20 . On Page 273 , changed countenence to countenance in the clause : "[1721-the widow] [I]0-i do n't know about that , " and [Tom]210-tom 's countenence darkened , ... Chapter 21 . On Page 288 , there are two quotes made by [the crowd]2136-the crowd in double quotes . [Twain]74-twain did not correct this in the 1899 version of the novel by [Harper]224-harper & amp ; [Brothers]2954-brothers . But these lines are surrounded by [Wilson]86-wilson 's narrative , which is already in double quotes . Therefore , [we]2944-we have used single quotes for the two remarks from [the gallery]2955-the gallery . • ' Why , it 's so -- [I]0-i never noticed that before ! ' • ' Why , that 's so , too ! ' Conclusion . On Page 302 , removed in from the sentence : "[0-i] But [we]1419-we can not follow [his]1420-his curious fate further -- that in would be a long story . " * * *
